urn:contentItem:5XWB-2DS1-JCX4-6154-00000-00Q&A: Cindy Cohn, protecting internet freedoms2020-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQ&A: Cindy Cohn, protecting internet freedomsThomas Peele

"EFF works to make sure that technology supports freedom, justice and innovation for all the people of the world."

The internet is forever changing, often not for the better. Threats to privacy and free speech grow daily. Government surveillance is legion. Big tech companies like Twitter and Facebook dominate the cyber world. Pushing back and raising legal challenges since 1990, the San Francisco based Electronic Frontier Foundation is often in the middle of the fray. The organization's mission statement: "to make sure that technology supports freedom, justice and innovation for all the people of the world."  This news organization recently talked to EFF's Executive Director Cindy Cohn, about the constant challenges of protecting digital freedoms.

Q: How do you balance freedom and protection? 

A: We have three major tools in our tool box, law, advocacy and technology. We have a bunch of lawyers on staff, that's our biggest team, and we (file) impact litigation. We make smart commentary and make sure your rights go with you when you go online. We do policy analysis and freedom of information act work. Our advocacy team makes that work relatable for ordinary people. Specifically, I think our membership is technological people, people who work in, and understand, technology. We have a really strong core with the people who build the tools.

Q: What are some of EFF's technological achievements?

A: "We have a tool called Privacy Badger for Firefox and Chrome that blocks third party cookies, those little pesky cookies that track you as you are going from website to website. Privacy Badger helps put you back in control of those. On the back end, we are part of a large group that built what's called a certificate authority. Certificate authorities are the ways that when you think you are going to your bank online, you know you are actually going to your bank online. We felt the web was very unsecure because people weren't using this technology. Sometimes you advocate for people to make their websites more secure, sometimes you just build them a tool to just make it dead easy and free."

Q: What do you do on the legal front?

A: On the legal side we do a lot of work defending coders, defending technologists. Especially in the realm of security, we find a lot of the people who are pointing out that our security is weak are finding themselves on the back end of legal threats and problems. We know that the way to get to a more secure digital world is to have a whole lot of people trying to find the holes and helping us plug them. We have a long standing relationship with the digital security community, especially the folks who are independent.

Q:  Recently, the private equity firm Ethos Capital bought the dot-org domain designated for nonprofits from the Internet Society and is planning to monetize it. How important is the dot-org domain?

Anyone who is watching what is happening with private equity in other sectors ought to be nervous. The central place for the public interest internet is dot-org. There is a strong and thriving public interest internet that really brings us a lot of the things that I think make the internet cool and weird and funky and awesome, from Wikipedia to the Internet Archives to the website for your favorite museum to the Red Cross.

Q: What's the threat?

A: We're going to see increased prices, and probably going to see degradation of service. Dot-orgs never go down. If there's an earthquake or a hurricane and you go to the Red Cross, RedCross.org is up. If you're in a country where there is civil unrest and you need to get information out, HumanRights.org is up.

Q: What is EFF doing on this front?

A: We've stepped in to try to save dot-org. ICANN's (The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers) contracts with the Internet Society can be cancelled if the Internet Society wants to materially change how dot-org runs. Our first step is to try to get ICANN to put the brakes on (the purchase of the dot-org domain) and make sure who ever runs dot-org is doing it in the public interest. Silicon Valley is full of people who understand this situation and have a stake in it and they need to make their voices heard.

Q: The California Consumer Privacy Act, the toughest online protection law in the country takes effect Jan. 1. What is EFF doing to make sure it isn't weakened?

A: We have been very involved in both trying to protect that law, trying to shore it up, trying to get comments in to the Attorney General about what the regulations ought to look like. There will be ongoing efforts by the big tech companies to water down the legislation (which, among other safety measures, allows consumers to learn what data companies collect about them). Some of the threats (to the new law) will happen in California, but some of them will happen in the form of federal laws that preempt stronger state laws. It's really like four dimensional chess about privacy legislation and we're trying to participate in as many of those levels as possible.

Cindy Cohn

Education: B.A. in English, the University of Iowa, J.D. University of Michigan Law School

urn:contentItem:5XGC-FX01-JCMN-Y27W-00000-00QA: Dark Design - the good, the bad and the very attractive2019-11-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQA: Dark Design - the good, the bad and the very attractive

Nov 10, 2019( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) 'Dark pattern design' is the practice of using software design to influence the behavior of users. The practice is becoming so large that the U.S. Senate is planning to pass a bill[1] to control its use, which can lead to addiction[2] in some extreme cases.According to Bhav Chohan[3], VP and Global Head of Design at intive[4], it is wrong to lump all UX design into the same bracket. Many companies are using User Experience (UX) design to encourage beneficial behaviors such as healthy app usage, nudging users to choose eco-friendly solutions or reduce distracted driving and so on. To discover more, Digital Journal spoke with Bhav Chohan.

Digital Journal: What is dark pattern design? Bhav Chohan: Dark pattern design harnesses the power of user interface (UI) and user experience (UX) techniques with the purpose of being intentionally coercive. Through the combination of strategic visual design and persuasive micro-copy, users can be steered to make unintentional purchases, give consent to invasive privacy settings, or simply spend longer using the application than intended. Once the reserve of magicians and hustlers, phrases such as 'misdirection' and 'bait and switch' are now commonly discussed on design forums as developers debate where customer-centric design stops and business-orientated tactics begins. These techniques are often so well disguised that users have no clue that their decisions have already been preordained by the business. This is why it's so important to raise awareness of the most common tricks being employed. DJ: Why is the US Senate passing a bill to control use? Chohan: The U.S senate is looking to tighten the reins on big web platform holders with 'over 100 million active users,' like Facebook, Google and Amazon. The act, which was dubbed 'The Deceptive Experiences to Online Users Reduction Act,' would make it illegal for companies to 'design, modify, or manipulate a user interface with the purpose or substantial effect of obscuring, subverting, or impairing user autonomy, decision making, or choice to obtain consent or user data.' The platforms offered by big tech have become essential parts of our lives as consumers, making the prospect of boycotting them highly unlikely for the majority of us. That's where government regulation comes in: The power that big tech wields could spiral unless it is kept under a close eye, and we need to make sure that these companies serve our best interests. DJ: Is there any evidence that dark pattern design can cause addiction? Chohan: Causing addiction by dark pattern design is certainly a bold statement. Dark pattern design is more likely to fuel addiction: Social media platforms often deploy tools to encourage their users to endlessly scroll and stay active in the app/on the website, with even simple features such as an endless newsfeed (Twitter, Facebook, Instagram) or the suggested video path of YouTube contributing to this. And it's not just on social media that we see addictive dark pattern design. Many video games build easy-to-spend models that hook players without them realizing it. There is even now a name for players that spend so much money on video game app extras - 'whales' - that actually provide most of the revenue of these gaming companies. DJ: Why do we find certain patterns so appealing? Chohan: When we get a notification from social media or go up a level on a certain game, we get a hit of dopamine in a similar way that we would after taking drugs. This fuels the appeal of dark pattern design, and it also plays a role in habit formation and addiction. That dopamine hit we get when we check social media keeps us going back and checking for another like or comment. The design of platforms that use dark pattern design is often straightforward and user-friendly, but also very visually appealing with bright colors, drawing users' attention to certain actions. The color red is often used to indicate unread notifications, giving users a sense of urgency to check it and respond. DJ: Are there examples of firms using UX to coerce positive behaviours? Chohan: Of course, we shouldn't lump all UX design into the same bracket. Many companies are doing quite the opposite and harnessing the power of UX to encourage healthy behaviors or conscious consumerism, nudging users to choose eco-friendly solutions or reduce distracted driving to mention a few. DJ: What is it that makes UX 'Good' or 'Bad'? Chohan: The intent of the company or developer behind it. If the intent is to encourage negative behavior or mislead the user into agreeing to something unknowingly then it is pretty clear that the design is meant to benefit the company and not the end-user. However, more conscious UX can actually deter users from using certain tools for too long and encourage responsible use. Contrary to spurring on the release of dopamine, examples of responsible UX might cause the release of the 'happy' neurotransmitter, serotonin. If an app has made the user feel calm, content, or like they are progressing towards a positive goal, serotonin is released, as it accompanies moments filled with intention and mindfulness. For example, meditation apps like Headspace would fall into this bracket. DJ: What can tech companies and users do to achieve a better balance in the future?" Chohan: Tech companies can increasingly adopt features that help their users get their technology use under control where it needs to. For example, Apple and Instagram, have already implemented 'screen time' features within their software. Being straightforward and providing users with clear tools to monitor and control their usage goes a long way to improve balance. However, as every aspect of our lives become digitized and we look to a future of smart cities and hyper-connected IoT fuelled lives, an abundance of new challenges presents itself to designers. It falls on design teams to facilitate greater dialogue with policy makers and challenge others on unethical practices that may influence negatively or cause risk or harm. As the quantified self and proliferation of data driven fingerprints of our lives, protecting trust and baking in principles that afford individual and societal gains and inclusivity is essential. For design teams this also means building in diverse perspectives through balanced worldly teams that intrinsically bring alternative experiences and viewpoints which can build robustness to areas of ethical, social or legal influence. urn:contentItem:5WSR-WD41-DYN6-W1XB-00000-00Q&A: Ex-Googler Harris on how tech 'downgrades' humans2019-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQ&A: Ex-Googler Harris on how tech 'downgrades' humansBY RACHEL LERMANAP Technology Writer

Tristan Harris wants to reverse the harmful effects he believes technology has had on all of us.

Harris, a former Google design ethicist, first rose to national awareness after a presentation he gave within Google in 2013 spread throughout the industry. In it, he argued that many tech products were designed to be addictive, causing people to spend too much time on them and distracting them from living their lives. He urged designers to alter their approach.

Harris spent more than two years pushing change within Google, but says he couldn't get traction. So he quit and started a movement called Time Well Spent, which eventually pushed companies such as Apple and Google to build screen time usage metrics and tools into their phones.

He has since widened his focus, having decided that many issues facing society today are actually connected and can be traced, at least partly, to the design of technologies we use every day.

This isn't about addiction, it's not about time. It's about what we call "human downgrading." It's a phrase that we came up with to describe something we don't think people are acknowledging as a connected system.

Technology is causing a set of seemingly disconnected things -shortening of attention spans, polarization, outrage-ification of culture, mass narcissism, election engineering, addiction to technology. These seem like separate problems, and we're actually saying that these are all predictable consequences of a race between technology companies to figure out how to scoop attention out of your brain.

Q: Where is the central place to fight this multifaceted problem that you've outlined?

A: Much like you say, "How do you solve climate change?" Do you just get people to turn off their light bulbs? No. Do you pass some policy? Yes. But is that enough? No. Do you have to work collaboratively with the oil companies to change what they're doing? Yes. Do you have to pass laws and mandates and bans?

You have to do all these things. You have to have a mass cultural awareness. You have to have everybody wake up.

This is like the social climate change of culture. So working on internal advocacy and having people on the inside of tech companies feel, frankly, guilty, and ask, "what is my legacy in this thing that's happening to society?"

We work on the internal advocacy. We work on public pressure and policy.

Q: How do you work with companies, and how are they taking to your vision?

A: Doing it from the inside didn't do anything when the cultural catch-up wasn't there. But now in a world post-Cambridge Analytica, post the success of Time Well Spent, post more whistleblowers coming out and talking about the problem, we do have conversations with people on the inside who I think begrudgingly accept or respect this perspective.

I think that there might be some frustration from some of the people who are at the YouTubes and Facebooks of the world whose business models are completely against the things we're advocating for. But we've also gotten Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, Apple and Android to launch Time Well Spent features through some kind of advocacy with them.

Q: Is there a path that you try to help map out for these companies?

A: They're not going to do it voluntarily. But with lots of outside pressure, shareholder activism, a public that realizes they've been lied to by the companies, that all starts to change.

There are multiple business models - subscription is one.

Would you pay $8 a month to a Facebook that didn't have any interest in manipulating your brain, basically making you as vulnerable as possible to advertisers, who are their true customers? I think people might pay for that.

So our policy agenda is to make the current business model more expensive and to make the alternatives less expensive.

Q: Washington is now in a huge debate about privacy and data and misinformation. Will that process deal with the causes that you care about by default?

A: I actually worry that we're so mindlessly following the herd on privacy and data being the principle concerns when the actual things that are affecting the felt sense of your life and where your time goes, where your attention goes, where democracy goes, where teen mental health goes, where outrage goes. Those things are so much more consequential to the outcomes of elections and what culture looks like.

Those issues connected together have to be named as an impact area of technology. There has to be regulation that addresses that.

My concern about how the policy debate is going is everyone is just angry at Big Tech. And that's not actually productive, because it's not just the bigness that is the problem. We have to name that the business model is the problem.

Q: Don't people have individual agency? Are we really in the thrall of tech companies and their software?

A: There's this view that we should have more self-control or that people are responsible for whatever they see.

That hides an asymmetry of power. Like when you think, "I'm going to go to Facebook just to look at this one post from a friend," and then you find yourself scrolling for two hours.

In that moment, Facebook wakes up a voodoo doll-like version of you in a supercomputer. The voodoo doll of you is based on all the clicks you've ever made, all the likes you've ever done, all the things you've ever watched. The idea is that as this becomes a better and more accurate model of you, I know you better than you know yourself.

We always borrow this from E. O. Wilson, the sociobiologist: the problem of humans is that we have Paleolithic brains, medieval institutions and godlike technology. Our medieval institutions can only stay in control of what's happening at a slow clock rate of every four years. Our primitive brains are getting hijacked and are super primitive compared to godlike tech.

Q: Do you feel there's awareness (within tech companies) that you wouldn't have thought existed two years ago?

A: There has been a sea change. For four years, I was watching how no one was really accepting or working on or addressing any of these issues. And then suddenly in the last two years - because of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, because of "60 Minutes," because of Roger McNamee's book "Zucked." I would have never suspected that Chris Hughes, the co-founder of Facebook, would be saying it's time to break up Facebook.

I've seen an enormous amount of change in the last three years and I can only bank on the fact that the clip at which things are starting to change is accelerating. I just want to give you hope that I would have never expected so much to start changing that is now changing. And we just need that pressure to continue.

urn:contentItem:5VP1-GVK1-JC8H-T3MX-00000-00Q&A: Former FCC Chair Tom Wheeler Says It’s Time for More Regulation of Big Tech2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisNEWSTAGQ&A: Former FCC Chair Tom Wheeler Says It’s Time for More Regulation of Big TechPatrick Kulp

As chairman of President Obama’s Federal Communications Commission, Tom Wheeler did much to dispute late-night host John Oliver’s memorable characterization of his revolving-door appointment as “the equivalent of needing a babysitter and hiring a dingo.”

His tenure at the agency saw the passage of strong net neutrality rules, broadband privacy protections and other pro-consumer reforms, most of which were subsequently dismantled by the Trump administration and a Republican-controlled Congress.

But Wheeler is optimistic net neutrality rules will eventually be solidified into law as well as privacy-focused regulation of Facebook, Google and other tech giants—an industry over which the FCC doesn’t have much jurisdiction but Wheeler had nonetheless hoped to influence. In his new book, From Gutenberg to Google: The History of Our Future, the former telecom lobbyist compares the process to other big shifts in communication technology throughout history.

Wheeler spoke with Adweek about the path forward for net neutrality, how his hopes of spurring tech regulation backfired and why the Pacific Telegraph Act of 1862 is still relevant today.

This interview has been edited for length and clarity.

Adweek: You started writing your book before your tenure at the FCC. What has been the biggest change in its direction since holding that job?Tom Wheeler: I think probably there were two: One was the thesis I was working on pre-FCC was how the nature of networks had moved from a centralizing force to a distributed force, and economic activity was following that force outward to the edge of the network, which indeed it certainly has. What I didn’t see at that point in time before the FCC and I certainly did see at the FCC was how the distributed network would create virtual centralization, and the ability to collect information on users and centralize, for instance, virtually in order to provide to sell services was something I think I had not seen.

Point two was how do you deal with that? And I said in From Gutenberg to Google that it’s never a primary network that is transformational but its secondary effects [i.e., the tech giants that operate on top of internet networks], and we saw that in history. And then what I tried to talk about based on my experience at the FCC in the second half of the book was a series of those secondary effects.

This is not, as the Trump FCC has tried to characterize it, a matter of some kind of contract relationship between an ISP and its users. This is a matter of basic concepts about how essential networks will operate. The Pacific Telegraph Act of 1862—just shortly after the development of the telegraph—had a section that said there had to be nondiscriminatory access to the network. In 1862, with the telegraph, there was net neutrality. And then of course that concept extended to the telephone, and somehow, this fiction has occurred where because what it transmitted is digital that somehow it makes it different because the telephone network had been analog—no, it doesn’t make it different.

Was there any similar political debate at the time?No, to the best of my research, with the Pacific Telegraph Act, it was kind of, ‘Of course we want to make sure there’s first come, first served nondiscriminatory access.’

Are you hopeful net neutrality will eventually be solidified into law?I’m hopeful on two fronts: One is the Court of Appeals for the D.C. circuit. I was in the courtroom when what was scheduled to be an hour of oral arguments on the Trump FCC’s repeal of net neutrality extended into four and a half hours of oral argument because the judges were very interested. So, I’m cautiously optimistic that they see how the Trump FCC did not make a fact-based decision and therefore did not follow the Administrative Procedure Act. And then I’m also encouraged by what the Democrats are doing in Congress.

What do you think of recent calls from various lawmakers for more regulation of big tech?I think that the concepts that we were promoting at the FCC, which basically boiled down to a duty to deal—what net neutrality was—and a duty of care—basically, what our privacy rules were—ought to apply across the board, whether you are a network company or a company that rides on the network.

The reality that we faced at the FCC was that we only had jurisdiction over the networks, and I just felt that that’s not a reason to wash our hands. Interestingly enough, I had hoped that we would build a model approach for networks, and then maybe the networks will turn around and say to the government that this is the same kind of rule that ought to apply to the edge providers [companies that provide online content and services like Facebook and Google]. Instead, they went to the edge providers and said, ‘Hey, you don’t want this rule to apply to you so let’s work together to kill it.’ And they got Congress to repeal the privacy rules, and they got the FCC to repeal the open internet rules.

Based on your historical perspective, where are we in that time line as compared to other shifts in information technology?Clearly, history tells us that the pioneers always make the rules. Their rules hold until those practices begin to infringe on the rights of others and the public interest. I think that where we are right now is we are identifying the fact that the rules thus far have been made by the digital companies, and it’s starting to have an impact on the public interest and the representatives of the public therefore need to step forward and make new rules.

Oct 07, 2015( InvestorIdeas.com: http://www.investorideas.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> NEW YORK, NY and POINT ROBERTS, WA - October 7, 2015 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Investorideas.com (   www.investorideas.com[1]) a global investor news source covering leading sectors including tech and mobile payments issues an exclusive interview with Mr. Thomas R. Szoke, President/CEO of ID Global Solutions (OTCBB:IDGS[2]). The company's core focus is in fraud management and payment solutions. Thomas explains his company's mission and gives insight as to where he sees the market is headed and how his company plans to establish a dominant role in this space.<nl/> Interview:<nl/>

Q: Investorideas.com<nl/> For investors that don't know your company can you give them an overview of IDGS, your various divisions and your products and services portfolio in mobile payments and fraud protection?<nl/> A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO<nl/> IDGS provides multi-functional secure payment solutions for open and closed electronic payment transaction networks. The company is focused on the growing need for fraud protection and identity verification solutions. ID Global Solutions was founded to pioneer key innovative approaches for the development, integration, and delivery of advanced digital identification and payment solutions.<nl/> Fraud Management and Payment Solutions are the two focus areas for IDGS. Within Fraud Management, the company offers unique Identity Verification solutions for Financial Services Organizations (IDComplete) and Governments (IDSolutions). IDComplete provides a secure real-time method for cardholder verification to eliminate fraud. IDGS' IDSolutions portfolio offers software and hardware products to deliver a wide variety of identification and verification capabilities for civilian as well as governmental applications.<nl/> Our Payment Solutions portfolio includes MultiPay, OnePay, and PaySpot. MultiPay provides end-to-end payment transaction processing technology. OnePay is a closed payment solution using a secure digital currency enabled by our mobile applications and backend systems for consumers and merchants in emerging markets. PaySpot is an unattended multi-functional payment collection and processing kiosk solution.<nl/> Q: Investorideas.com<nl/> Can you explain IDComplete's impact on the payment process, the issuing bank, and ultimately how the consumer is impacted to eliminate fraudulent transactions?<nl/> A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO<nl/> IDComplete aligns to all industry standards. IDComplete does not impact existing players or processes within the acquiring network external to the issuing bank. Today, prior to a transaction being authorized, issuing banks determine the approval of the transaction based primarily on the account status of the cardholder. There are other criteria employed by issuers to determine fraud that are predictive in nature including buyer behavior pattern, location, merchant type, and the transaction amount.<nl/> IDComplete compliments these by providing real-time cardholder verification. This is done in parallel to the issuer authorizing the transaction based on cardholder status. IDComplete is triggered to deliver a notification to a registered mobile phone to approve or deny an active transaction. Within the notification is the date, merchant's name, and the transaction amount along with the option to "approve" or "decline" the transaction through a proprietary secure pin delivery method.<nl/> Q: Investorideas.com<nl/> A lot of the big tech giants are entering the mobile payment and credit card and identity fraud protection space such as Apple, Samsung, and Google. Everyone has a different approach with levels of security in biometrics and other security measures so what differentiates your company's technology and how can you compete?<nl/> A: Thomas R. ID GLOBAL SOLUTIONS ("IDGS-L") - Q&A Interview; How Id Global Solutions Plans To Provide Global - Business And Consumers Fraud Protection And Mobile Payment - Solutions

Investorideas.com (www.investorideas.com) a global investor news source covering leading sectors including tech and mobile payments issues an exclusive interview with Mr. Thomas R. Szoke, President/CEO of ID Global Solutions. The company's core focus is in fraud management and payment solutions. Thomas explains his company's mission and gives insight as to where he sees the market is headed and how his company plans to establish a dominant role in this space.

Interview:

Q: Investorideas.com

For investors that don't know your company can you give them an overview of IDGS, your various divisions and your products and services portfolio in mobile payments and fraud protection?

A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO

IDGS provides multi-functional secure payment solutions for open and closed electronic payment transaction networks. The company is focused on the growing need for fraud protection and identity verification solutions. ID Global Solutions was founded to pioneer key innovative approaches for the development, integration, and delivery of advanced digital identification and payment solutions.

Fraud Management and Payment Solutions are the two focus areas for IDGS. Within Fraud Management, the company offers unique Identity Verification solutions for Financial Services Organizations (IDComplete) and Governments (IDSolutions). IDComplete provides a secure real-time method for cardholder verification to eliminate fraud. IDGS' IDSolutions portfolio offers software and hardware products to deliver a wide variety of identification and verification capabilities for civilian as well as governmental applications.

Our Payment Solutions portfolio includes MultiPay, OnePay, and PaySpot. MultiPay provides end-to-end payment transaction processing technology. OnePay is a closed payment solution using a secure digital currency enabled by our mobile applications and backend systems for consumers and merchants in emerging markets. PaySpot is an unattended multi-functional payment collection and processing kiosk solution.

Q: Investorideas.com

Can you explain IDComplete's impact on the payment process, the issuing bank, and ultimately how the consumer is impacted to eliminate fraudulent transactions?

A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO

IDComplete aligns to all industry standards. IDComplete does not impact existing players or processes within the acquiring network external to the issuing bank. Today, prior to a transaction being authorized, issuing banks determine the approval of the transaction based primarily on the account status of the cardholder. There are other criteria employed by issuers to determine fraud that are predictive in nature including buyer behavior pattern, location, merchant type, and the transaction amount.

IDComplete compliments these by providing real-time cardholder verification. This is done in parallel to the issuer authorizing the transaction based on cardholder status. IDComplete is triggered to deliver a notification to a registered mobile phone to approve or deny an active transaction. Within the notification is the date, merchant's name, and the transaction amount along with the option to "approve" or "decline" the transaction through a proprietary secure pin delivery method.

Q: Investorideas.com

A lot of the big tech giants are entering the mobile payment and credit card and identity fraud protection space such as Apple, Samsung, and Google. Everyone has a different approach with levels of security in biometrics and other security measures so what differentiates your company's technology and how can you compete?

A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO

Our solution has been built to eliminate card fraud. IDComplete is the only product in the market that provides real-time verification of identity in a proactive manner. All existing fraud prevention approaches in the market are re-active and do not prevent card fraud in real-time. For example, sending a SMS or push notification after a transaction is complete asking the cardholder to contact the issuer in the event of fraud is re-active. Today, cardholders are put into a position to reconcile their transactions whereas IDComplete offers the ability for the cardholder to police their transactions by embedding cardholder verification in real-time prior to any transactions being processed.

Q: Investorideas.com

As someone in the sector, can you give us some insight and perspective as to where you see card fraud trends heading both in the US and globally? And on that note, where is your primary focus geographically?

A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO

As a backdrop, global card fraud exceeded $16 Billion in 2014, which analysts forecast to exceed $35 Billion globally by 2020. In 2014, approximately $8 Billion of card fraud loss occurred in the USA and half of $8 Billion card fraud occurred during card not present (CNP) / online purchases. This equates to more than $4 Billion of collective loss to issuers, cardholders, and merchants.

IDGS's geographic focus is to roll out our IDComplete solution for eliminating card fraud in the US market. Our initial strategy is to focus on the card not present (CNP) / online purchases because they are not being addressed by the implementation of the new EMV standards.

Q: Investorideas.com

You recently announced a deal with MultiPay SAS, which is headquartered in Bogota, Colombia (http://www.multipay.com.co/). Can you give us a brief background for new investors and an update on the progress of the company?

A: Thomas R. Szoke - President/CEO

Multi-pay S.A.S. is a well-established multi-functional payment gateway company providing traditional credit card processing services, domestic and international wire transfer services, mobile operator pre-paid account re-charge services, and various closed system payment solutions for numerous customers in Colombia and Peru. Since the acquisition the company has been integrated into the IDGS structure and has expanded its core engineering and delivery teams to increase the capabilities of our platform and deliver more services to new and existing customers. In addition, since the acquisition the company has secured additional contracts with banks and enterprise customers for money transfer and payment processing services.

IDGS provides multi-functional secure payment solutions for open and closed electronic payment transaction networks. The company is focused on the growing need for fraud protection and identity verification solutions. ID Global was founded to pioneer key innovative approaches for the development, integration, and delivery of advanced digital identification solutions.

Presentation

FRANCES VAN REYK, HEAD OF IR, QANTAS AIRWAYS LIMITED: Good morning, everyone. I'm Fran Van Reyk. I'm the Head of Investor Relations for Qantas, and I'd like to wish you a warm welcome to the Mascot Campus and Qantas' 2019 Investor Day. And to those of you who've chosen to join us via the webcast, a warm welcome to you, too.

Before we get started, because many of you are unfamiliar with the campus, I'd like to play a video that outlines the safety and evacuation procedures.

(presentation)

FRANCES VAN REYK: I'd like to acknowledge the traditional owners of the land, the Gadigal people of the Eora Nation, I pay my respects to their elders past and present.

Before we get started today, a couple of housekeeping items. First of all, as I said, the event is being webcast and recorded. So please be aware that your image may be captured and transmitted. To those in the room, feel free to connect to our guest Wi-Fi. You would have received the details when you registered this morning. We have a couple of bathrooms on this level, just to the left of myself. And there are others throughout the campus. Just ask one of our graduate team members who are wearing gray polos today, so you'll be easy to identify them for directions to other bathrooms if you need them. And they can help you with any other questions you might have.

Finally, can I ask you to set your phones to silent for the courtesy of all of the presenters and others in the room. We have a fantastic day prepared for you, including a taste of the customer experience that Qantas is famous for. There are 3 presentation sessions in total, with Q&A at the end of each of those sessions. I'd ask that you keep your questions until the end of each session, so we can keep things moving.

So our first presenters today are Alan Joyce, the Qantas Group CEO; followed by Andrew Parker; Vanessa Hudson and Rob Marcolina. To kick us off, Alan will set out the global context in which we operate, and he'll take you through our strategy to build on our sustainable competitive advantages.

Alan, please come up to get us started.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE, CEO, MD & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, QANTAS AIRWAYS LIMITED: Thanks, Fran. Can I also acknowledge the traditional owners of the land, the Gadigal people of the Eora Nation. I pay my respects to elders past, present and emerging. I'm afraid you've -- I've got the triple whammy today. Not only have I got an (inaudible) to cope with, I speak fast, but I also have a head cold. So we were joking, we probably need close captions for this phase of it. But since I'm only giving the summary of what you're going to hear, you're going to get the details from everybody else a little bit later, which means you get a second chance or hearing what I've said.

I will start off by talking a little bit about this week. Qantas reached its 99th birthday on Saturday and having flown for that length of time, the business has adapted and changed its model, changed its approach. It's gotten its business to adapt to the situation over those decades in a quite an amazing way. And it has built up over that time, some sustainable and competitive advantages that we think are quite unique in this marketplace and give us an advantage compared to any other airline group, certainly in this market, and we think close to what's the best practice in the world of aviation.

We also -- when you look at aviation and how it's changed over that period of time, technology and the forefront of use of technology has been a big driver in giving sustainable advantage. And we're going to talk a lot about that today because you'll see how technology is also shaping all parts of our business more so than it has done at any time in the past. Of course, one of the most important things that is the focus of every discussion we have in the business is around the safety of the business. And safety for us is our #1 priority. It is part of the DNA of this company for those 99 years. If you go back to the start of that history, it was a core part of what our founders wanted in the creation of this business. And it's something that we always have to be focused on, and it's something that we try to encourage in our business to always be uncomfortable about. In fact, what we do on the safety side of this business is what I think I've been trying to replicate on the business side, never getting complacent, never getting to a stage where you assume that you're automatically the best in everything that you do. And 20 years ago, we had a very bad accident where an aircraft, a 747, ran off the runway in Bangkok, the QF1. Over 30 people were injured, and I think complacency had set into our business at the stage. And we looked in and saw that as a wake-up call and we changed a lot of what we did in the cockpit, a lot of what we did in the safety management system, and we put in place something that I think is best practice around the globe.

We also don't see safety as a competitive advantage. We have a safety conference that we do once a year. We invite our competitors into that safety conference because, for us, we want the entire industry to continue its amazing journey of continuous safety improvement. And that for us, I think, is more important than anything else that this industry does.

It's also changing landscape because in the last 5 years, I think more so than ever in our history, there's been a real focus on cyber -- security in cyber and safety online, protecting the data and protecting the information and protecting the systems that we have. And what we've done over the last few years, and we'll talk a little bit about this when we go through some of the investments that we've made, we've spent a lot of money making sure that the same safety and security focus we have in operations also apply to the cyber world. And I think we -- I hope are one of the leading companies in that space as well.

Now the aviation industry, the first flight, as you know, took place in 1903 with the Wright Brothers. The first commercial flight took place 11 years later in 1914. We've had 100 years of aviation operating commercially. And for that first 100 years, the aviation industry did not cover its cost of capital. That is a terrible statistic. But the good news is in the last 5 years, the aviation industry as a whole has covered its cost of capital. I think Warren Buffett said back in the 1980s that there should have been a farsighted capitalist at Kitty Hawk and killed Wright Brothers before they destroyed all that value. But in the last 5 years, he's invested extremely heavy in the aviation industry, knowing it has turned that corner.

And this year is probably still going to be one of the best years in aviation overall. The business has gone to make $28 billion, slightly down on last year at $30 billion. But it does vary dramatically between the different regions around the world. Over half the profitability is being made in North America with $15 billion of that profits. And what we take from the North American market is some of the capacity, discipline, the structure of the market with 4 players having 80% market share that is a (inaudible) consolidation. Decent returns to be made, which have been beneficial to consumers and customers up there because the American Airlines are now investing for the first time in a long time in product and services.

What's also interesting in Europe, there are pockets of where there are good profits to be made, and a big learning for us is particularly what IAG have done in their home strength of their markets in the U.K. with British Airways and in Ireland, with Aer Lingus, in particular, which have given them significantly good returns in a very competitive market. What also we've seen in Europe is that there has been a large creation of a large number of airlines that have, through the difficult periods we've seen in the last couple of years for higher oil price, have disappeared from the market because they've not been viable in that region.

What's also interesting in those stats is what difficulties the Middle Eastern carriers are going through. This is the second year in a row that we've seen over $1 billion worth of losses in the Middle East. And what we've seen as a consequence of that is the importance of the Qantas and Emirates partnership within that context. And you'll see a little bit later Tino talking about the benefits that both carriers get from that arrangement in that region. And I suppose the big takeaways from this is the benefits and the growth that we're seeing in the Asia Pacific region. We have a big advantage of where we're located. In our region, the profitability has taken a bit of a hit at this year. And when you think that the Qantas Group makes around 10% of that $6 billion profitability in the Asia Pacific region but less than 0.5% and of the population of the regions based here in Australia, this shows you how well the group is performing in a very high-growth region and a region that has a huge amount of potential for the future. And we will be spending a bit of time today, particularly in Gareth's presentation in talking about how we're going to take advantage of the growth in traffic that's likely to take place in Asia Pacific.

In fact, if you look at our projection on 2037, the Asia Pacific market will be bigger than the North American market and the European market put together. And we're already seeing huge growth in the region and with 17 of the top 20 routes in the world being based in Asia Pacific. And in fact, Qantas is the largest player on 2 of the top 20 routes. The second largest route in the world, Melbourne-Sydney and the 12th largest route in the world, Sydney-Brisbane. And with the population of those cities also growing, it is a very big growth opportunity for us domestic as well.

Now a couple of years ago, we talked about the global forces, the megatrends that we believe are going to shape our business into the future. Some of these can be seen as opportunities, some of them can be seen as challenges. Whether they're opportunity or challenges, your strategy and your business needs to be able to cope with them and take advantage of them when appropriate. And the ones that we're going to be talking about a bit today are still the same as a couple of years ago, they are megatrends so they shouldn't change between these investor presentations. But we're going to talk about the new centers of customer demand and political influence, and particularly through what Tino and Gareth are going to cover about the opportunities that we have in this region with that growth.

We are seeing some volatility, obviously, in the short term. We are seeing slower economic activity because of the trade wars, both internationally and domestically. But we are still seeing very significant growth in this region, not as big as we were expecting a few years ago. And we are seeing some volatility in oil prices and in the Aussie dollar, which Vanessa is going to go through how the business is going to be able to cope with that in the short term.

We will be talking a lot about digitalization and the opportunities that that creates. We will be talking a lot about the new aircraft technology, both for Jetstar and for Qantas, that changes the range of routes that we can operate and the economics of routes that we can operate, which we think is a big benefit for the business. There is a big change in customer preferences. The rise of generation Y and Z is changing. People's aspirations for the companies they want to work for and for the brands that they want to buy from. So we will be talking about our license to operate, and Andrew Parker will be going through this in quite detail and how important that is for these younger generations. And Rob Marcolina will also be talking about how we cope with the changing skill sets that we need in the future and how we're engaging the workforce of the future to be able to work with us.

And then finally, but no means least, we'll also be covering off the implications of climate change, particularly what we're doing to minimize our impact on the climate, we're -- we've been working on this for a long time. We have one of the oldest carbon offset programs of any airline on the globe. We have the largest carbon offset programs. But it's not only about carbon, it's about other activities and waste. And Andrew will be taking us through a lot of detail about what we're doing in that space.

Now I'm going to play a video for you because once we get to our 100th year, which we are in now, we look back, as you do a reflection about what we've achieved and where the company's come from. And what we're seeing is that companies that have a strong purpose, companies that are very clear on that purpose, are companies that outperform the marketplace. And it's been my fundamental belief that Qantas has always had a strong purpose. Sometimes, we haven't defined it as clearly in terms of the statement, but people knew what we represented and knew what we're trying to achieve. So we have a video that goes through our history, goes through what we've done over 100 years, defines the purpose that we've delivered for the Australian economy, the Australian people and for our employees and sets that up as the purpose for the next century. So I'll play the video, we'll go through the strategy there.

(presentation)

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: What we do on an ongoing basis, I think that that statement that we take the spirit of Australia further covers just about everything that the company does. Whether it's helping local communities through the bushfires, which Andrew will talk about what we've done in recent times, whether it's through floods, through drought, whether it's through at the activities we do in regional communities like capping airfares or giving regional airfares for those communities or through the democratization of air travel to making air travel easier for a lot of people through the low airfares that Jetstar operates. Or whether it's through projects like Project Sunrise that overcome the tyranny of distance. Everything the company has been involved in, is being involved in and will be involved in fits under that purpose. And I think it's good for our people, good for our shareholders and good for the community, in general, to know that there is a clear purpose for the organization overall.

In order to deliver on that purpose, in order to lever for all of the stakeholder groups, we believe that it's very important for us to have a sustainable competitive advantage that we can leverage, we can use to continue on delivering. And when you look at where the group is today, there's clearly a number of areas where that sustainable, competitive advantage exists. First of all, it is in the brand. We have 2 amazing brands, probably the most iconic Australian brand. And you could see that with the direct flight that we did last week from London to Sydney. It got unbelievable coverage around the globe. It was there for major scientific reasons. We will get a lot of benefits from a safety point of view well with those flights. But we had the Prime Minister and the leader of the opposition, who came to that celebration, and he said the most amazing things about the company and the brand. Why? Because they believe in it. They believe that this brand is iconic, that this brand does represent Australia on the global stage. And with a lot of the activity we do, it actually promotes the most positive things about Australia to the rest of the globe.

But we also have an amazing brand in Jetstar. It's one of the top brands in Japan, as Gareth will take you through. It's one of the top brands here in Australia. And it's seen for what it delivers every day as value for money and making air travel accessible to the global public. And I think those 2 brands and how they work together as dual brand know-how is a unique competitive advantage that no other airline in the world has.

And I wouldn't underestimate the dual brand advantage. Andrew David is going to take you through in some detail how we make that work. A lot of airlines out there have tried to create dual brands, a lot of airlines have failed in this space. And Qantas does really well in this domestic market in particular and how it uses both brands at different segments of the market to complement each other.

We've also had a look at the home strength that we have here in Australia, and the advantages that that creates for us. When I talk to our peers about the fact that 35% of all credit card expenditure in Australia is on a Qantas earning credit card, they're blown away by that stat. When we show that in the domestic market, we have over 60% capacity share that translates into over 80% revenue share and over 80% of the profitability. That home strength is unique, and doesn't exist I think in any other market around the globe. And when we look at the information and the data we have on our customers, the fact that 1 in every 2 households are members of frequent flyer scheme and we can leverage that information to provide product and services that are uniquely designed to our customers also gives us a big advantage. And of course, underpinning all of this is the culture and the people that we have, whether it's the safety culture, the customer service culture, the can-do attitude of our people that really gives us, we think, a competitive advantage in the business. And Vanessa will take you through the strength that we have on our balance sheet and our cash performance, that's the biggest strength we've had in some time that allows us to continue to invest in all of these different areas and stretch our competitive advantage even further compared to those other airlines.

And we do see this as a virtuous circle. And there are a couple of virtuous circles that are important for us to look at the dynamic associated with them. You'll hear a lot of our people here talking about the interactions with other parts of the businesses. And while we manage the business of P&L, where we have a domestic P&L and international one, and loyalty one, everybody knows that the businesses still interact with each other. And the strength and the performance of the businesses are achieved through leveraging that interaction. So while there is on international leveraging the corporate dealing model that we have where, for domestic passengers, we give the best network by miles domestically and using that to make sure that we have those corporates flying internationally, whether it's leveraging that international, Jetstar, and domestic network to give a proposition to our loyalty customers that gives them access to over 5 million seats each year to redeem their points on that very important family holiday. They are all interlinked and that continuous interaction is where the strength of the group comes from. But it's also important that we look at this business, not only from a shareholder point of view but also from a customer and employee point of view. And we have said now for a long time that the stakeholders in this business are equally important. And you can't, at the expense of delivering for shareholders, forget about your customers and forget about your employees. And we think we have a virtuous circle have been achieved in the business today, with record customer satisfaction just about across every part of our business, leading to record shareholder returns, which also leads back to employee engagement. And our employee engagement every year continues to improve on the previous years. And again, I think we'll talk a little bit about those interactions and how important they are for us.

What we will go through now as part of the presentations that each of the GMC is going to talk about is how we then look at the global megatrends and the global forces, translate that for us into what is 6 different components and pillars of the strategy and then how we deliver on each of those parts of our strategy. And each of the GMC members will take you through a different part of that strategy in detail with very clear targets over the next 5 years about what we want to achieve and a clear measure of what success looks like.

So let's talk about them very briefly. And you'll get a lot more detail from each of the GMC members. The first is really about the domestic business. It is the core of the profit engine of the group. We think the sustainable competitive advantage that we have on domestic can continue to be enhanced. We are working quite extensively on our transformation program. And in the next year ahead, there will be a lot more focus on cost than revenue. And over the next 5 years, we believe that there is a path for us to achieve significant improvement in margins.

We look at the best practice around the globe and we see that full-service airlines are getting to margins in the high teens. So we are and will continue to target that for Qantas Domestic. And low-cost carriers get to margins in the low 20s. I should say, well, they sound like good margins, about half of the profitability that the airports in Australia make. So there's a lot of room for us to continue to enhance margins even above those levels into the future.

International has been awarded for some shareholders in the past, that international could go back to producing the losses that it did in 2013. We think the international business has been fundamentally transformed. We think the international business has some significant upside still to come. And Tino will take you through the big benefits that we're going to get from replacing the old technology of the 747s with the 78s over the next year, the benefits we're going to get from leveraging the partnerships that we have globally, which 3 of the biggest partnerships we have are all relatively new. They have been put in place over the last few years. And there's still a significant upside, particularly for the American Airlines partnership. And we'll be talking about how this positions us well for Project Sunrise. We will be very clear that we won't do Project Sunrise unless there's a clear business case and a business case purpose to hurdles. But we'll see -- we do see Sunrise as a huge growth opportunity for us in a space where we have a unique competitive advantage, which we believe is very hard for anybody else to replicate.

Gareth will be taking you through the opportunity within the Asia market, tell you how we pick the routes that we're going to operate. We can fly to so many different destinations, but we could lose a lot of money picking the wrong destinations. So we're going to talk about how we filter the right places to fly, how we identify the right opportunities and how we can get competitive advantage in each of those areas. We also will talk about some of the significant opportunities we have in translating our dual-brand strategy into markets like Japan and how significant that opportunity is for the group going forward. Steph will be taking you through the investment in the customer experience. Again, getting this right across the entire business is going to be key to maintaining that competitive advantage. But we're also going to spend a lot of time today on a number of areas of investment that we've made in the last couple of years on distribution, on personalization and on revenue management. They go hand-in-hand. And we think we are in the lead compared to a lot of airlines around the globe, but in particular, and what we're doing in this home market to enhance our competitive strength in our home territory. And Steph is going to explain what these terms mean, what the investment is delivering and how that opportunity will allow us to achieve the targets across each of the individual businesses.

Olivia is going to take you through the loyalty program. And in 2017, we made a commitment that this business by 2022 will have earnings between $500 million and $600 million. We're going to show the progress we've made since '17 and what is in the pipeline to get us to that target and reconfirm that target. We believe that there is significant upside still in the loyalty program. It's interesting that our competitors are buying their loyalty programs back at huge cost. We have dodged a bullet by never selling it and never -- we will never sell it because that business is too valuable and too linked in to the other parts of the group. And we want to go through where we think there's upside in the loyalty business over the next few years.

And as I said, what's going to be really key to getting all of this and achieving all of this is engaging our people to move with us and making sure that we have the workforce that we need for the future. And over the last few years, we've actually hired more [digi] workers than we have pilots or engineers. And the likelihood is that when we project that out over the next 10 years, that's where huge growth for us are. So we will probably have more digi workers, then we'll have pilots or engineers in the business in the next decade. But we still need to make sure that we have the right skills in the right areas. And Rob will take you through how we can deliver on that.

We did an amazing job I think in 2013, with the $2 billion transformation program. And one of the things we continuously get around the organization is, is this transformation finished? Is transformation over? And what's very clear in our business, and has been clear for the 99-year history, is that transformation never ends. We want to show as part of today, that it is ingrained now as an ongoing program that is going to deliver over $400 million each year. It needs to be that number in order to offset the continuous inflation that we have within the business, but also to offset the continuous advantage that the consumers get with lower airfares. And so again, Rob is going to take us through a lot of detail of what those projects look like, examples of where we're getting leverage with new technology and how we position the company for digital revolution that's taking place going forward.

So when you bring all this together at the end of the day, and if you look at how we measure success, what that strategy is, we have a simple scorecard of what we think success looks like. And on this scorecard, we say that if that strategy is delivered and implemented successfully, there's no reason why Qantas Domestic shouldn't get to an 18% margin within the next 5 years, Jetstar Domestic to a 22% margin, Qantas International achieving over 10% return on invested capital during that period and Jetstar achieving over 15%, particularly given some of the investments that we're making both in Qantas International and Jetstar International in new aircraft types that we think will be significant to the potential earnings from those businesses. And we're reconfirming our commitment by 2022 that the loyalty program will have between $500 million and $600 million in EBIT earnings over that period of time.

So hopefully, by the end of the day, in each of the presentations, you can see the road map to this scorecard being achievable. We believe it is achievable. And that will mean that we will have the financial strength still to continue to return significant funds to shareholders, the financial strength to invest in new fleet and new aircraft, the financial strength to invest in customer service and customer experience and the financial strength to continue to return and invest in our people.

So that's about the outline of today and the outline of where we are. I will wrap up with one other item. And this, to us, is very important, which is our sustainability and our license to operate for the next 100 years. I look at what happened on Friday with the Prime Minister and the leader the opposition there and think of the hard work it's taking Qantas over 100 years to establish this iconic brand, and for people to absolutely being convinced and supportive of that brand. We know we have to be conscious of that every day. We know that going forward for the next 100 years, we need to make sure that we're continuing to invest in that license to operate. And that is typically doing the right thing by people every day. Andrew is going to take you through a lot of details about how we do that, how that's ingrained in the business and how the business comes up with delivering for the Australian public.

And the model that you went through earlier about how we judge, which ones we get into is really key because we could do a hell of a lot in a lot of different areas simulates.

OLIVIA WIRTH: Yes. And I think you can see the example of mortgages. That's sort of the first time we've really gone above the line with ANZ on a significant mortgages proposition. You might be aware of the ANZ CEO gave some details around that at their financial results. And that showed that they've been at 30% increase in terms of the mortgages they've seen in a certain period of time, which is directly related to the marketing campaign and partnership with Qantas Frequent Flyer. So we do know that there is application of our points beyond the credit card. We know there's value in it.

And to then to Alan's point, that gives us confidence that there's a whole range of other payment opportunities out there for us to work in partnership with our banking partners on.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: Great. Other questions? Up here.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Back to Steph. There's been a bit of controversy around -- with Qantas Direct about excluding certain intermediaries from particular fair offerings, both from a legal point of view and from a public point of view, generally -- retailers generally. Do you see that issue going away in due course? Or is it going to be something you're going to have to face up, too.

STEPHANIE TULLY: Can you repeat the first part of the question? It was hard to hear.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: Some intermediaries precluding them from the Qantas distribution channel.

STEPHANIE TULLY: Yes. I mean, we are not close to anyone joining the Qantas distribution channel. So it's a channel that we created deliberately to invite everyone in, whether some parties choose not to join. We're not actually seeing it. We've got 98% of Australia and 75% of the rest of the world signed up to it, GDS to advance their technology, which they're all appreciating as well. So I'm not sure if this.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: So Jetstar has and some of the OTAs because they were -- we're making sure that our distribution is clear that going through jetstar.com as an example, is still the lowest cost way of doing it. And if these OTAs want to charge a booking fee on top of that, that's up to them, but it needs to be clear and transparent to the customers. And we have been hard-nosed about that, and we will continue to be hard-nosed about it because I think that's just fair to the customers that they're aware of that. And there's no -- there's no other processes going on behind, and maybe it's relating to that. But I haven't heard anybody say they were unhappy with the Qantas distribution channel.

STEPHANIE TULLY: No, we've got positive feedback. I think it's early days, and it's partly a journey for the whole industry. So we're still waiting for the GDS to advance their technology as well. But the next year is going to be a good year. I think you'll get more and more of that experience technically through GDS and through non-GDS the customer and the agent that still has the choice.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: Great. Other questions? We exhausted everybody, have we?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: They look exhausted.

ALAN JOSEPH JOYCE: They look exhausted. It looks like, and I think I might then do a wrap up. Can I thank everybody for the presentation?

So I'll keep this brief. I think it's fair to say that when you look at what you saw today, it's very clear that we are an organization that have been operating for 99 years. We're a business that has a very clear purpose. We do take the spirit of Australia further. We believe that that served us well for that period of time. And we are very focused on making sure we deliver for all of our stakeholders.

And Andrew Parker went through in great detail what we're doing for the community. What is that -- what we're doing on the environment, what we're doing for regional communities, what we're doing for Australians in need. We think it's really key to our continuous prosperity that we have a focus on our social license to operate. And being part of that community, have been involved in that community is really a core part of what's made us successful for 99 years.

What you have also seen, I think, from Steph, Olivia, in particular, is our focus on the customer and how we believe what we've been doing with the customer gives us competitive strength. We have a very clear focus on caring for the customer, rewarding and the customer and knowing the customer. And I think each parts of what they're doing in their individual businesses goes across the entire group and delivers a sustainable competitive advantage.

Steph took you through what we're doing in distribution, the Qantas channel, what we're doing in personalization and what's we're doing in revenue management. That's only starting to kick in. I think it is substantial competitive advantage here in this market and has huge upside to it. We also then had each of the businesses talking about their sustainable competitive advantage.

Andrew David talked about the domestic market in terms of our market strength, our dual-brand strategy, our network size and the benefits that that are giving us. We are seeing that the market structure playing out to the benefit of Qantas, 98% by 2 airline groups, of Qantas' strength in those other areas, giving us over 80% of the profit builds.

We have given a target over the next 5 years as a consequence of that. If you go back a few years, people were thinking that the domestic market would never get back to $1 billion profit. Domestic market did. Our next target was that we would get Qantas to $1 billion profit. We did. Our next target now is that we get to margins of 18% for Qantas domestic and 22% for Jetstar domestic. They are achievable around the rest of the world, and given the structure in this market and our competitive advantages, we think we should be able to do that.

Tino gave a very clear path through for improvement in Qantas International. He showed that aircraft technology is changing that business. There's huge upside to the 787s replacing the 74s. That is a transition year next year in order to do that. But the benefits that we're now seeing from our partnerships worldwide with the 3 joint ventures, in particular, with the joint venture with American Airlines, again, having big upside that isn't in our numbers today gives us confidence that the international business will return its cost to capital of over 10% through the cycle and positions us well if we can make the business case work to actually launch Project Sunrise.

The performance of Perth-London has given us that competitive advantage that we think it's hard for other people to replicate. And if we can get the business case across the line, Project Sunrise, in my mind, is like the big bets we've made in the past. It's like Emirates, it's like Jetstar and it's like the work that we've done on Loyalty.

And we saw from Gareth this huge opportunity we have with the Asia Pacific region. The opportunity that we have with growth for markets that are going to be phenomenal over the next few years, but that we are going to be very disciplined on the markets that work for us. I think also a sleeper in the group is what's happening in Japan. And Gareth showed the opportunity there. We think it could be bigger than Jetstar Australia. It could be as profitable as Jetstar Australia. It's a slower pace and that happened here because of the way the market works, but the opportunity in Japan is amazing.

And you probably saw our secret weapon, Jetta, downstairs. I hope everybody didn't have a cuddle because that's inappropriate to do in the office space. What Jetta -- Jetta is a symbol of the brand and simple of how much it's penetrated in Japan. And finally, I think you saw that 2 years ago, we gave a target for loyalty. We said that we would get to $500 million to $600 million by 2022. And I think Liv has shown that we're on track to achieve that and has given us confidence to reconfirm that today. And that is why we've also given the targets in the other businesses. The 15% return on invested capital for Jetstar, the 10% for international, the 18% margin for Qantas domestic, the 22% margin for Jetstar. Now if all of them come together, we will be delivering for the shareholders because that means significant upside and shareholder returns on top of the $4 billion that we've returned to shareholders over the last 5 years on top of what we've seen in terms of the investment we've made in aircraft and customer. It continues to allow us to do that. And it is a virtuous circle. I believe, fundamentally, that you get the community right, you get the customer right and you get the employee engagement right, you can deliver for shareholders and continue to deliver. I think that's what Qantas has showed in the last 5 years. And hopefully, this plan and this strategy will say, for the next 5 years, we can even exceed that.

So can I wrap up by saying a few things? First of all, can I thank Fran and the team. There's a huge amount of work, as she said, that has gone into this. The team have been working very late nights on weekends. Can I thank everybody that presented and their teams behind it? You probably noticed the reference between how the teams work together. The one thing I think I'm most proud about is how well the team works together. And there is general support, and there's general interaction. And we know that the group can only be successful if all of these businesses if all of these segments if all of these different functions work together to achieve it. And typically, what you're seeing here is how we work on a day-to-day basis, which I think is a great credit for the senior management team.

I can wrap up by saying, I haven't got the ability to bribe with points here because we don't do that. But what we do have is a bar downstairs. Fran has said he's going to put her credit cards -- her credit cards on the table. Yes, to get points. So if anybody wants to join us for a drink. And I'm going to wrap up with one last video. And this is a video that talks about the century that we've just gone through on Qantas. How we're proud of that history, how we're proud of where we've come from and how this positions us well for the future. Thank you very much, everybody.

Oct. 20 -- Qatar Central Bank issued the following news release:

H.E Abdulla bin Saoud Al- Thani, Governor QCB, recently delivered a lecture entitled" Change is the Only Constant" at Carnegie Mellon University's Dean Lecture Series.

The lecture provided an analysis of the challenges facing banks in today's world, especially with regard to the competition from "digital-only" financial service providers.

H.E commenced the presentation with an overview of the stable macroeconomic environment in Qatar over the past couple of years, along with the improvement in domestic and external balances. Relatedly, H.E highlighted the initiatives that have been undertaken by both government and QCB to promote a solid and diversified economy as part of Qatar National Vision 2030 (QNV 2030).

The presentation featured Fintech as one of the major key challenges facing banks at present, driven by changes on both demand and supply sides. In this context, H.E remarked that QCB is providing the enabling regulatory framework. As part of this, it is proposed to introduce Fintech strategy, accompanied with strong risk culture and other related controls.

A lot of large Big-Tech players are entering the payments and financial services market, due to healthy margins, putting pressure on business models of banks. In this changed milieu, banks need to take on board the following five elements: customer loyalty; create value; increase efficiency; improve resiliency and nurture talent. Contextually, support is needed from other stakeholders such as supervisory and regulatory entities and educational institutions in order for banks to win the battle.

In conclusion, H.E stated that in this dynamic environment, if banks can provide competitive services, gain customer loyalty, attract talent and safeguard security, they will have an advantage over digital-only financial services providers. How fast and how effectively banks can readjust themselves remains to be seen.

Source: Qatar Central Bank

urn:contentItem:5Y2S-M8X1-JDJN-62JC-00000-00QatarDebate discusses need for regulation of big tech companies2020-01-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQatarDebate discusses need for regulation of big tech companies

QatarDebate sponsored the event at the World Economic Forum in Davos in collaboration with the New York Times. Photo Credit: Pasha Kalachev for The New York Times.

Big tech companies are transforming economies and societies, and influencing people's lives, but cannot be trusted to regulate themselves, speakers argued at a QatarDebate-sponsored event in Davos, held in collaboration with The New York Times.


The Oxford-style debate organised by the Qatar Foundation member and the US newspaper, on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum's 50th annual meeting, saw six speakers go head-to-head as they discussed whether a new regulatory board needs to permanently change the tech landscape, or if companies should be allowed to self-regulate.
"I want you to think about the age we're living through. It's an age of anger as trust in governments and major institutions is broken, because of the failure to protect people and share prosperity," said Sharan Burrow, general secretary, International Trade Union Confederation, arguing for the motion that big tech cannot be trusted to self-regulate.
"The impact of big tech companies is not helping because they're subverting privacy, competition, and indeed democracies as they're becoming global monopolies. And who has the right to monopolise power? We've never accepted it from governments; traditionally we've never accepted it from corporations."
Lisa Witter, co-founder and executive chairperson, Apolitical, told the debate: "Big tech is calling for this regulation – CEOs are asking for help," referencing tech bosses such as Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, Microsoft president Brad Smith, and Sundar Pichai, CEO of Alphabet, who last week said there was "no question" that AI needs regulation.
However, Rebecca Masisak, chief executive officer, TechSoup, argued against the motion, saying that self-regulation requires a multi-disciplined stakeholder approach. "Can we trust governments? Governments have agendas, too," she claimed. "At times, they're really not keeping in mind what's best for citizens. And governments are not global, whereas the problems are.
"We can trust big tech to self-regulate with a model that engages a diverse set of global stakeholders, businesses, governments, and academia, and also big tech employees and grassroots civil society. The several million employees in big tech across 50 countries have the potential to meaningfully influence big tech to self-regulate."
Malcolm Frank, president, Digital Business, Cognizant, suggested that big tech companies are already, to an extent, regulated by the public. "Switching costs are unbelievably low for this industry," he told the debate. "You don't like Google Maps? Go to Apple Maps. Don't like Bing? Go to Google. With such insanely low switching costs, digital companies are already properly regulated in many important ways."
