urn:contentItem:5XJY-6411-DXH2-6004-00000-00Qualys Inc Analyst & Investor Luncheon at QSC 2019 - Final2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexis112019a12834519.719Qualys Inc Analyst & Investor Luncheon at QSC 2019 - Final

Corporate Participants

* Laurie MacCarthy

Qualys, Inc. - Former EVP of Worldwide Field Operations

* Melissa B. Fisher

Qualys, Inc. - Former CFO & Principal Accounting Officer

* Philippe F. Courtot

Qualys, Inc. - Chairman & CEO

* Sumedh S. Thakar

Qualys, Inc. - President & Chief Product Officer

Conference Call Participants

* Chad Schieken

* Senthil Selvaraj

* Wendy M. Pfeiffer

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: (technical difficulty)

going to give us an update on the product initiatives. He'll be followed by Laurie MacCarthy, our new EVP Worldwide Field Operations, newly promoted, I should say, not new to the company. He's going to talk about the scalable sales model. She'll be followed by myself who will talk about our scalable business model. And then Sumedh's going to come up and moderate a customer panel who will talk about security in the age of the digital transformation.

So just a reminder, if people could have their cell phones off, and we'll do Q&A at the very end. And welcome, Sumedh. Thank you.

With that, I would love to turn it over to Philippe.

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT, CHAIRMAN & CEO, QUALYS, INC.: Okay. Here we are. So thank you very much for coming. And in fact, the -- on the panel after that will be also for you the opportunity to really ask questions to the panelists so you could get the direct feedback. And for those who are attending -- did I lose now -- or did you just reduce the volume, okay? So for those who are attending the conference, also, this is the opportunity for you to directly speak with customers and get their feedback. I mean as you probably -- as you all know, we're a pretty transparent company. And I think that's, we believe, the way it should be.

So with that, if somebody gives me a clicker, here it is. So I'm going to start to give you the presentation that I gave this morning. I'm going to make it a little bit shorter. And I don't know why this thing is not bigger here. Okay, very good. Thank you. And are we in the -- we're now in projection mode. Here we are, perfectly.

So we had this morning, Dick Clarke, which gave us very interesting -- how many of you could attend Dick Clarke -- okay, about half of the audience. So it was interesting because as you all know, Dick Clarke was essentially the first cybersecurity czar. And what he did was to really highlight the sinister side of the Internet fundamentally, where Internet, as you know, went through that first period of everything was fantastic and happy, like hippy, and we could communicate freely across the world. And then, of course, things started to change, obviously. And that's what he alerted that there's really bad actors and nation states bad actors as well.

And so [he rolled a book] and recently addressing how sophisticated everything is coming. And there's absolutely necessity that we all have now today that security of that new environment, which you could call the cloud of the Internet, whatever you want to call it, is becoming front and center. And it affects almost everybody.

And so -- and then he presented a kind of positive view of, at the end, thinking that today with all the new technology that bad guys are, of course, using that this is also the opportunity for us to essentially rethink security in many ways and essentially start to -- and this is more what I've always believed that we could now -- we're in a position of now building security into the new fabric, and that's a very major change.

And so with that, if I go back to 2012, this is something that I've already said -- and boy, you've got that lights that come right in your eyes. So anyway, so I'm going to try to move away from it, but I don't want to be behind the podium. Anyway, and then this is not turning to the right direction. We'll dance around. So fundamentally, I gave that speech in 2012, which I have to say was not really that well received. And because I was essentially saying that trying to continue securing the current networking environment that we had was essentially becoming almost very difficult, if not impossible. And of course, at the time, there is a lot of resistance from the security and the IT people to the cloud. And that's what it was, not very well received.

So the point I was making then as well was if you look back at the evolution of computing, essentially, mainframe computing came, as we very well know, from the vacuum tubes to the day when finally IBM gave up in a way and invested $1 billion in Linux so they could essentially encapsulate their old mainframe world and then emerge as a middleware and a service company.

And then during that time, because of the technology of semiconductors has improved, now you have the minicomputer era, which came in. And then the client server came in. And major change in the way computing was delivered, and we'll discuss about that later. And now today, we're absolutely in -- now we can say today that the cloud is taking over. There's absolutely no question about that.

So if we again look back about cloud computing, we know today that we're just at the beginning of even more changes. 5G is coming. And what about quantum computing? What about the ability to have genetic storage and so forth? And when is that going to come? And there's many other things that we have not even thinking of. The acceleration, if you go back to the industrial revolution, this new technology wave like the electricity -- I don't know why -- why are we picking in and out of the -- my mic is moving. Okay. So when we were essentially at the beginning of the industrial revolution, you have the steam engine, the electricity, a lot of things converging, which has actually significantly enhanced and changed the human condition.

Now today, we're on the verge of a significant, thanks to the Internet, which is becoming absolutely -- connecting billions of people who now have the ability to change information, to learn, to improve the human conditions. And that's where we see all this acceleration of technologies in so many different ways. So we are just at that beginning, really. And now the Internet is really taking over, or if you prefer, cloud computing.

So it brings a lot of changes with it, obviously. And of course, those who adapt to the change and adjust and/or drive the change are going to need to thrive. Conversely, those who don't are left behind. And that's -- these are the law of evolution. Nobody can change that.

So if I go back to the computing. When you look at the mainframe, the mainframe were distributing the computing power to the large companies who could afford it. And there were big data centers protected by walls which are very difficult to enter. The communication to the outside world was pretty simple, private phone lines with [adapter]. And who was securing that? The IBMs of this world, this control data. And so that's why it was a relatively easy environment. That's what they were doing. The minicomputer, which was similar, was the same.

Now when client server came in, this is where everything changed. So the client server now is distributing the computing, so the minicomputer to the labs and to the departments. So this was the era of the DEC, the Primes and the (inaudible), which, by the way, disappeared pretty quickly because they could not, and we'll talk about that later, adjust essentially to the new client server world.

So now certainly, that coming power was delivered to all the people in the enterprise. And nobody paid much attention to security because you were inside of the walls of the enterprise. And also, it was a little bit more complex because you didn't have any more one vendor. You had the people manufacturing the servers, the operating systems, the database, et cetera, et cetera.

And what was that architecture? The architecture was actually servers, the LAN, and of course, the PC. And so securing all that was an afterthought. No need to do that. And absolutely, of course, through the floppy disk, which I'm sure some of you may remember, not all of you. Suddenly, viruses came in, and that became essentially the first, oh, what about security? How could we do that? And this is where McAfee started and other companies.

And then the need to communicate more and more became very important. And then suddenly, you had to open up the walls of that house that we had. And that was the era of the firewall and on and on.

And then the more we were opening up -- the more doors and windows we were opening, and the bad guys, of course, took advantage of all of that and especially that now that you are connected on the Internet, you are not disconnected anymore. So now you could -- you're not into this air gap networks anymore, so they could use the Internet to go back into your homes.

And then we saw absolutely that era where more -- because security has so many different facets, then we had to bolt security on and on and on, and that's why I made in 2012 that comments that guys, we cannot continue bolting our security and through all of these things. So today, we have to adopt cloud-based architecture even for security because you have to secure that world.

And what is, again, the component of the cloud? It's not some magical computing power some place in the heavens. It's essentially massive data centers with infinite computing power, infinite storage capabilities which are all now much easier to patch, by the way, much easier to secure. And of course, the access can be better controlled.

And then you have the Internet as the means of communication. And the Internet needs to be secure. And today, we're not yet at the level where we should be. And I essentially applaud the efforts of Google, which started first by essentially saying, guys, we need to have a set of communication and make it ubiquitous everywhere and have succeeded in doing that. I created the Trustworthy Internet Movement to try to really push that. But of course, Qualys was too small and it was not really our place.

But now today, Google has embarked into a new initiative, which some people start to criticize, of course. We absolutely applaud that because they say, guys, we need to change the Internet protocols, which were never designed for security. How could we today spoof website? How could we spoof e-mails? And what about the security of DNS and on and on? And that, I believe, is the work to be done. And I absolutely encourage them to really move full speed ahead behind Google. That's the domain of the Facebook, the Google, the Amazon, the Microsoft, the Azure because they are leveraging that Internet. So at the end of the day, it's in their own interest to make sure that the Internet itself becomes significantly more secure.

And then on the other hand, what do you have, is now a significant different type of tablets, of phones, of devices that connects and, of course, which need to be secure with multiple actors as well again. So now there's still that same problem that you have multiple actors, which will have to work together to try to put all these pieces together from a security standpoint so we can finally build the security in.

Now what happened, of course, with client servers -- I discussed the complexity of security became absolutely crazy. And when you look today at that and you know all of that, then the amount of security compliance companies out there, it absolutely doesn't make any sense anymore.

And on the top of that, we still are being breached big time. Why? Because these different security solutions, they don't work well -- they don't work together. They were never designed to work together. And so -- but you need to have the information that each of them have. So how do you do that today?

Okay. So you put a SIM, another solution on the top of that. And you try to make all that information coming into that SIM. But that SIM doesn't know how to correlate that information. Because how do you know that the information which has popped up from that way, that device and another information popped up on that same device by another application is essentially the same device? You don't even know. So that's why the SIMs have not only significant cost that they add because of all that complexity of taking the data, manipulating the data, et cetera, the number of false positive or false alerts, if you prefer, is absolutely significant. And the problem when you have false alerts is that you cannot automate. Because if suddenly, you're not going to eliminate something which is false, what are you going to do?

And so this is why today, we need to totally rethink security. And that's where the digital transformation is coming in and the usage of this cloud-based technology. So fundamentally, the world is changing, and it's changing finally very fast.

I thought it would have happened 10 years ago. And -- but now I can tell you, it's happening now. So -- which, of course, is very good for Qualys because we have been cloud-based since 1999 and leveraging first the nascent technology, which was the Linux, Apache, MySQL and PHP, which is not really that great, but that was the beginning. And then suddenly, today, there's a plethora of new technology, Kafka, Cassandra, ElasticSearch, which are all coming, by the way, from the cloud vendors themselves -- from the private cloud vendors, which needed to develop this technology for themselves so they could scale. And what they did very shortly is to put that in open source because they realize that they could not develop all of these technologies themselves. So in fact, they were sharing between themselves this technology via the open source, which they greatly simplified because the early days of the open source movement, which I'm bold enough to have been part of it, where the (inaudible), where you have these kind of purest people where everything had to be pure and so forth for the great of human kind and so forth, so they were so complicated to put your hands on that open source. But now today, they simplified all of that to the point that we, Qualys, have benefited significantly from that.

If you listen to the presentation of Sumedh, after that, you will see we're using today about 140 open source engine where absolutely we're indexing 3 trillion data points on our ElasticSearch clusters and on and on. And without this technology, we could not essentially have built the platform today that we have built. And we have been working on that since quite a long time.

So the digital transformation now affects everything or the cloud, if you prefer, cloud transformation. And essentially, I'm going to discuss about it affects the market itself as you -- as we'll see. It affects, of course, the current security vendors. And it affects also the security professional and the company. And the key is, how could we fundamentally take advantage of all of that and embrace this new solution because those who will embrace them are going to be the one that succeeds.

So with that, today -- that I mentioned that in one of our earnings calls that we see another thing is today, clearly, the market used to be the enterprise market, the consumer with the antivirus. Today, we see 4 different markets shaping up. One is a market of the large enterprises, which, of course, has a huge channel today to retool everything, fundamentally. So they could accelerate, if you prefer, their business, their flexibility. We see today what the banks are doing. Now today, they are -- the silos are crumbling, as I can give you many examples of that. You see today that if you go in India and you want to create a bank account, you just pick up your phone and you just authenticate yourself via the Indian government ID system, and then you take a selfie and then you create the phone -- your bank account. That simple. All of that because of the underlying -- the infrastructure, which is behind, which allows to do that automatically and, of course, via the Internet or via 5G or whatever.

So today, the challenge of these companies today, all of them, the large ones, they have to do that themselves. Because you cannot go to another outsourcer and say, "Okay, do everything for me." Their business is so core, so they have the knowledge of their business. So they need to decide what am I going to retool myself, what I'm going to put into the cloud, into these private clouds and have then rebuild, if you prefer, their underlining computing infrastructure.

So of course, from a security standpoint, it means, okay, I cannot continue with that plethora of operations, 9 agent on average on my endpoints doesn't make any sense. So consolidating the stack is really the new game.

And then from there, okay, now I need to retool. And now, of course, is that new era. Now we see DevOps rising in these companies and which are the ones retooling almost everything.

And of course, security has to be built in because, today, if you want to respond in real time, as you must do, you need to be really capable of also having good data; and second, being able to really respond as solidly and as automatically as you could. And so that's totally a new game.

And then there is the cloud security vendor themselves, which today are building security into their platform. And we're very, very proud of having worked with Microsoft, and there's a presentation this afternoon of Microsoft about building security into Azure. So we made an announcement about a couple of weeks ago, I don't know -- about a few days ago or 2 weeks ago that now our cloud agents are built into Azure.

So now security in this new environment has totally changed. You go to the Azure Security Center, you click on the link. And automatically, you have the view of all your resources on Azure, thanks to the Qualys agent, which is embedded there. You click on the second link, and you essentially now have the security and compliance posture of all of those assets. And you click on the third link, which has nothing to do with Qualys this time, which is the ability to remediate what is called your playbook. And then you have your playbook and then you push on the button and you remediate. So security in that new -- in this new cloud environment has become a click, click, click, nothing to install, nothing to update. The only thing you do is that you bring your policy.

And the agreement we made with Microsoft is that Microsoft is offering that for free to the customers. And of course, behind that, there's a significant opportunity because there's so much more solutions that Qualys can bring to the table, some that Microsoft probably at some point in time will also bundle and some others.

So the world has now changed. So these vendors, of course, they have to make the decision versus -- build versus buy. So -- and they will build some things. Today, you go to Amazon, and they have built their firewalls, essentially. And the world is also changing. We're moving into now you have serviceless environment. The technology is changing so fast, it's absolutely incredible.

And then all of these other companies on the planet, which don't have the resources of the big guy, they still have to do their digital transformation. They don't have the technical people, and I think they're going to be relying on the new generation of MSSPs as security is concerned or MSPs. And again, these are people which are going to embrace this cloud technology and preferably not building that themselves. So they already look at companies like Qualys and say, by the way, can you give me all of that and then use these platforms to essentially now use that instead of them building it like they've been currently doing, now suddenly bringing their expertise and the human added value to essentially help those other companies.

And finally, there's a totally emerging market. And if you were there this morning, you will have seen on Sumedh's presentation that we're moving as well into this OT and IoT world, of course, because of the architecture that we have.

And that's a totally different market again. You have to secure all these devices. And then again, you have to build security in. There's no way you can bring your box on these devices. And you need to have the automation. So when you look at this architecture, the example that I give to almost everybody now is the home, today, the way we secure our homes while exactly leveraging these cloud technologies. We put sensors in our home everywhere to detect not only just the break-ins but also to detect -- to look at the temperature, change the temperature, if this is what we want to do totally remotely across the Internet. We can always see if somebody knocks on our door from our phone and then we can open the door or close the door. All of that is absolutely automated essentially.

And then you still have the problem that I alluded earlier of these false alerts. The last thing you want to do is to have false alert because if there's an incident, if there's a fire or there's a burglar, automatically, this incident result system, which are in the cloud some place that alert the cops and the fire marshal. So you don't want to have false alerts.

And you have the thing, which has been solved today, which is a very good example of our newest instrument, talking about our new, next-generation of SIM as we call it that we're building. The goal of what we are doing today is not only having scale, so we can really manage millions and if not billions of devices, hundreds of millions of devices, but also being capable of responding as much or rapidly as possible. That response is very key.

So today, if you leave your dog in your homes, then the dog is going to move, it's going to bark, et cetera, an intruder alert, so suddenly, you will have the cops rushing in, which obviously is not very good. So what do they do today? And this is existing because they have cameras. And of course, they can hear and analyze the voice as well. So they will analyze if it's the voice of your dog and they will analyze if you take the fingerprint of your dog and then they eliminate the false alerts. So you can now leave your dog, which has another advantage in terms of security because if somebody wants to come into your house, they're going to bark, which is another level of security that you have built in by leaving your dog, if you prefer.

So the world is changing big time, as you can see. And the other message I would like to leave you with. Today, a lot of that security has been built around the fact that the network has been increasing and increasing and becoming almost like a cancer growing. And there, of course, you have now to put more firewalls and more of these and more of that. And that was because this Internet technology were not mature enough. But today, they are there. Yes, as I mentioned earlier, we are using 140 open source engines today back end. And of course, without that, it will have taken significantly longer. So there's been a lag for this technology to come and mature, but they're all there.

So what we're going to see, and I can see it already happening, the network is shrinking to be replaced by the Internet, which, by the way, doesn't cost you a penny, essentially, very little. So that is another major change. So what it does, if you're now a vendor not only you are faced with the problem of rearchitecting and move like the minicomputers, they could not really re-architect the solution. I remember Ken Olsen, and I think you remember as well that it was attached to his minicomputers, and that client server was (inaudible) for life was not good enough. The reality, they could not rearchitect, was far too complicated. And so that's the challenge #1.

Challenge #2 is the distribution channel challenge. The channel of IBM were not the channel of DEC. The channel of DEC were not the channels of Novell. The channels of Novell were not the channels of Microsoft, et cetera. Why? Because suddenly, that computing power, the cost is going down. So you're not selling multimillion-dollar solution with a lot of professional services. You end up buying -- selling something, which is a much lower value and much less services. So the channels that are dying are the first one who takes it on the chin and have to adapt. And the cloud brings absolutely a disruption, which is absolutely phenomenal. Because the channel is the distribution -- the cloud, sorry, is the distribution channel. You don't need -- these are managed with sales guys and these technical people, et cetera, to bring this solution to your customers. And that's what we have done today by launching our free Global IT Asset Inventory, which is absolutely, from a technical standpoint, something absolutely incredible what we have done, where we can automatically help companies of any size, very small or very large, to create their own Global IT Asset Inventory across on-premise, endpoint, cloud, containers, web applications, et cetera. The complete view, totally automated view. Totally free of charge.

Why can we do that? Because try -- just try and I don't know if Sumedh will have the presentation. Do you have that presentation of how we enable our Global IT Asset Inventory or not? Anyway, this -- he gave the presentation this morning, which is totally straightforward. It's very easy to do. And why? It's because, again, we're using this cloud technology. And the cloud is the distribution channel, major change.

And then on the top of that, to make our life even more complex, the buyer is changing. The buyer is not anymore the CIO, is not anymore even the CISO. Its becoming DevOps. And these are engineers. And that's a totally different game changer. Again, these engineers are the one driving the digital transformation of their enterprise. They are the new buyers. And these guys are engineers. And so if you have something for them, say, "Okay, show me your code." Okay. If they like it and say, "Okay, great. By the way, don't tell me, give me the code. I'm big enough. I'm going to evaluate it. So please leave me alone."

Second, if they call you back because if they don't like it, they don't even call you back. They call you back and say, "Oh, I like your code, but I would like you to do this and this. Can you do that?" Okay. If you said, yes, they come, they discuss. And then they will call you back and say, "Now, I'm very much interested in the road map." But by the way, it's not the road map of the vendor anymore. It's their road map. So they are the ones driving the show. And that's something that Qualys understood that very early on. And everything we've been doing have been always driven by customers. They are more intelligent than we are. And that's another very big change in that industry. It's not any more the [people] of computing or security bringing their knowledge to the masses. I mean the masses, they know better. And these DevOps people, of course, they are engineers at heart.

And as you very well know, now they are faced with another bigger challenge as well, which is the business model change. Why does the Wall Street now want to see companies having a subscription-based model? It's because that's what the customers want. They are part of the shelf wear. That 4 years, 6 years down the road, they are going to rip off everything, put the new software and, of course, a lot of shelf wear. So we have entered into essentially a consumption-based model, which is the way the customers want to essentially procure technology. So that's for them.

So of course, what about the security professionals in that industry? So we have to adapt, not only the vendors, but also all the security professionals. And so that adaptation, in fact, requires that we don't think anymore in terms of silos, where you've got the security people doing this, the IT people doing that, the compliance people. It has to be a team now, and it's almost a cultural revolution in the company that needs to take place. And we see that already happening. We see that today, and I will give you one example in a minute, whereby it's a mindset change. Companies have to adopt the notion of that -- of security has to be built in, fundamentally, that this is a Board-level issue. We have to secure the data of our customers. We have to secure their privacy. We have to do all these things; if not, we're not going to be in business for very long. And we need to use all this new technology to become more agile and have better connections with our customers.

So today, it's a teamwork effort. And as I mentioned earlier, security now is at the Board level, front and center. Why? Because of 2 things. One is GDPR, all this regulation, which are now coming at you big time. And the second one is all data breaches. The last thing you want to do is to have these massive data breaches and then the lawyers coming at you and the regulators coming at you. That's [why it is not] possible.

So this is where we are today. And I will give you one example, which I can share with you because, Societe Generale, which is a Qualys customers, and I would tell you the story behind it, I think it's important, just published on LinkedIn a fantastic video. Can you just give us an idea of how many vendors -- cybersecurity vendors you have in each of your environments? It might not be something that you even know, but -- and then what's your plan over the next 2 to 5 years to consolidate vendors? And how does Qualys fit into that plan? That would be really helpful.

WENDY M. PFEIFFER: Operationally, I have about 60 vendors for my ops. I also work for an operating system company where -- and vendors certify to our OS. So I've got hundreds and hundreds that are running as well for certification purposes. I do not expect to dramatically consolidate, but I do expect to only use a handful of tools over the next 3 to 5 years for my core operations, ultimately, because everything we're doing is moving to autonomous mode and training the machine is best with focus. And so focus really helps us to get to autonomous operations, which then helps us to get to very fast response, and that's the goal for all of us operationally.

CHAD SCHIEKEN: So unfortunately, I can't answer your question because I personally just don't know the number of tools. I can tell you that, thematically, we're going through a process to really focus on not just deploying tools, but measuring the effectiveness of those tools. And then I can tell you specific to Qualys, that's been a major area of partnership with us and Apollo's team throughout the past, I don't know, 6 months or so to really make sure that we're getting the leverage and effectiveness.

And my own personal experience in our environment has been, time and time again, when questions come up, like, "Oh, is that really a false positive?" Or, "Did you really scan that correctly?" Or, "Hey, someone accuses a scanner of knocking something over, creating a disruption," literally, I want to -- I don't want to quite say 100% of the time because maybe I'm forgetting something, but I cannot recall a single instance where we've gone back to Qualys and said, "Hey, you just did something in our environment that didn't work or you offered us a particular piece of value that we didn't get."

So I can tell you that these things have fared well for the tools that I'm personally managing. And across the organization, there's definitely this idea that if we're using anything that's not adding as much value as others that maybe we need to invest more in the things that are working and maybe just invest less on things that aren't. That measurement will be ongoing.

SENTHIL SELVARAJ: Yes. My answer to one of your questions is similar to what he mentioned, which is I do not know how many vendors we have. But obviously, the big banks have hundreds of vendors. But one thing I'll tell you, this is a public information. I mean, our regulators, especially the OCC, when they announce -- when they come up with a quarterly guidance for U.S. -- the consumers as well as banks, they rate vendor management as 1 of the top 3 risks. So cyber, vendor, operational risks are always in the top.

So vendor management risk is not vendor's risk. It's our risk. The way vendors can do anything, but I think ultimately, the onus is on the banks. I think from that perspective, we have a very good third-party vendor management program, which comes up with the first onetime assessment of inherent risk and everything, so that's how we evaluate various vendors. And we do have a lot of vendors that support in this space, from a DLP perspective, from CASB. I mean, obviously, with the growth of cloud, there are various products. But one thing I would tell you within the limits of what our ethics committee has provided me is Qualys has been our customer for quite some time for the last several years, even before we started this digital transformation and data center consolidation, all these programs. So yes, definitely, I think I would mention that one.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Great. Any other questions?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: We were constantly struck by how few subscriptions some companies use relative to the Qualys platform. The description he offered up this morning clearly shows an enormous amount of value that can be had, a lot of automation, a lot of orchestration, yet we don't see that reflected in 50% of customers buying 7, 8, 10, 12 subscriptions. So my question to you is, where are you guys in that? Are you using the full platform? Are you using 2, 3 subscriptions? And when you see what he offered this morning, do you see, "Hey, this is something that I could really extend big time into my organization." How impressed are you with what they're showing here in terms of delivering the automation and orchestration and solving the problem of false positives and the like?

SENTHIL SELVARAJ: I can give a very general observation and then, Wendy, you can pick it up. I think one of the things that got my attention from Philippe's presentation this morning was how the paradigm shift has taken place across the 4 channels, mainframe to minicomputers to client server technology and cloud. I think the one notable thing there was it used to be contained to a handful of few companies and then -- I mean, to a whole bunch of companies and employees, but now with cloud, everyone is in it. Like, any company can come up with a bunch of nerdy technology guys partner with Stanford or something like that and then start a company. So I think from that perspective, it's very difficult. I mean, whatever Qualys has done in terms of number of products is impressive, but it's very difficult from a corporate standpoint where you can say, "Hey, there's an opportunity for us to consolidate," because I think there are varying needs and that's how our vendor base and the needs are spread out.

WENDY M. PFEIFFER: So I'm excited about Qualys' new play. It matches the consumption model that I'm trying to drive. The potential challenge with any model like that is that all the components may not be best-in-class, especially when you're talking about acquisitive platforms like a Salesforce, for example, where the components are not best-in-class. In this case, the development of those components was in-house and was specific to an overall road map. So that is interesting to me.

I can tell you that it matches a consumption model that we're -- that we want to have in IT, but financial cycles really are a factor in terms of how quickly we can change models and modes. Typically, as a CIO, in general terms, I'm not speaking about my current job particularly, but in general terms, we have financial targets that we meet around CapEx and OpEx consumption. And so if I'm going to change up a model of consumption, kind of writ large across a category of spending, then I do that gradually because the financial model (inaudible) so that's a challenge, right? And so I think what I look at when I'm changing from CapEx consumption to OpEx consumption, I'm looking at a -- I'm looking at maybe a 2- to 3-year pivot, right, a 2- to 3-year gradual move. That's actually okay. That matches this sort of model that Qualys is offering. So it's one of the things at Nutanix as well, we are moving to a subscription sales model, and we're seeing that same cycle. Our customers need that 18 to 36 months to pivot their consumption models and to plan that financially. However, it's a very attractive model once we make that pivot.

The last piece is that the laws have just recently changed as well. So we used to -- if we signed up for a SaaS-type deal, right, we would look at that on a month-to-month basis. Now we have to look at the total potential price of that contract. And so that's adding another layer of complexity in terms of how quickly we -- taking care for GAAP and all those other things kind of pivot our models.

Ultimately, if I'm going to displace multiple vendors today with a single platform but the consumption model will ultimately be the same, then I'm going to do that over, let's call it, 18 to 36 months. But I'm going to actively go there if I have best-in-class point solutions and it reduces my complexity because complexity is still the enemy of security and scaling and all those things.

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT: So I would like to a second. Let say that what's interesting that we might be (inaudible)

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Have you turned on, Philippe?

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT: Okay. Yes. I don't know. Okay. So thank you very much.

So what is very unique with the Qualys model, especially because of security, this is a security component. The challenge -- the reason why security has been best-of-breed is because the solution that eliminates false positive and false negative rises naturally to the top. And that's how we became the best warranty management solution because we are aware of the solution, which by far, has a less false positive and false negative. And we measure that even to the point that we are better than Six Sigma, which means for 1 million scans that we do, we have less than 3.2 errors.

Now what is interesting with our platform approach and that cloud approach and that's -- I learned that many, many years ago is that the solution that we build on the top of our platform become naturally and very effectively best-of-breed. Why? Because we can correlate information that this other application cannot do. As a result of that, we can eliminate much better and much faster the false positive and false negative. So all the solutions that we are building on our platform are almost build to be best-of-breed, and that's very unique. Again, it's an architectural component.

CHAD SCHIEKEN: It's interesting. I'm going to respond -- I heard 2 parts to your question. The first part, you mentioned one aspect, false positives. And the question was also, what's the reaction to some of the announcements today.

So around false positives, I would say false positives are not a problem. And anyone that says they are, at least with this particular technology, isn't looking at the data. Because the data is clear. Like, nothing's perfect, right? So like I just went through our false positives that we saw in the past, I don't know, 2 or 3 weeks, and we have an environment that is truly at scale, right? I don't know if we're the largest customer. I doubt we are the largest, but we're certainly up there. And I think we had like 4 or 5 false positive requests, very, very few. And what -- and so even if someone -- so even if I had more, right, the thing you do in response to a false positive is, usually, 88% of the time, based on the Qualys knowledge base, you go -- you try to patch it. Well, the patches all look for the software and the version. So if you try to apply a patch that didn't need to be applied, it would just stop. And so I don't need to do this. So no matter how you slice the false positives problem, that's a bit of a trap. It's almost like an ad hominem attack against the program to say, "Oh, you give me a false positive, so I'm not going to play in your sandbox." So I'm at the Qualys conference. I'm going to stand on that soapbox, right? This is my one opportunity to do it.

The -- what I will say is around the product announcements, what I saw was things that I consider really forward-looking. So I was actually telling Sumedh just a few minutes ago, I had a colleague approach me, looking for better prioritization of the results that we're giving them. And we have an internal project going where we're trying to find a different way to weight the vulnerabilities that we have using things like maybe there -- whether there's an exploit that it just exists, whether it is how mature is the exploit, right? And all these other factors as well as far as the CVSS score and the prevalence of this, and we're experimenting with this model to see can we find something, right, that would allow us to focus on the few things that are going to really have a significant impact on our risk. And then when we're done with those things, reassess either new things came in at that same risk level and we iterate at that high-risk level, maybe we don't get out of there, or maybe we solve the high-risk problems and now we have the time and resources to go after the lower risk, right?

So we've been experimenting with that and running some tests. And I wouldn't have had to do that work if Sumedh had to be able to push that out last year, right? So my reaction is very positive. I'm happy to innovate. We have a very innovative culture. We love to tinker and experiment. We try to do that. We never do that at the expense of the customer, but we try to do that in a way that allows our people to fully use all their different skills because we have such a talented team. At the same time, every time we build something and a vendor comes along with a solution that already -- that solves the same problem, I can now take those resources and apply them to something else, right? And I'd rather write checks to solve certain problems than put my people's time on it. So prioritization is a great example of something that the industry needs for a variety of reasons.

And the VMDR platform is very interesting to me. There's different environments where I can see that being incredibly applicable. My own use cases, as they typically do, don't encompass all of the needs that, that particular solution provides for, meaning it's not the same teams that find the problems and fix them, right? We -- most of our technology is tied up in what we -- the products and services we offer our customers, not sort of like the IT back office. So the teams that provide those products and services are the same teams that fix those problems in this DevOps model, right? So for us, it may not be as applicable, but that doesn't mean I don't see sort of the value. And Sumedh knows, if I had a different view, I'd be sharing that one.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Do you use the Cloud Agent? And if not, why?

And then the second question would be, are you more likely to buy more Qualys products if you do use the Cloud Agent?

CHAD SCHIEKEN: Okay. So we are beginning to take a more agent-based approach in our organization. We've traditionally had an architecture that was based on network scanning. That architecture served us very well for a long time and will continue to. We are finding that there are specific use cases for the Cloud Agent that are really compelling.

So for instance, inside a CICD pipeline in a lower environment, it becomes very easy to get a sort of federated product and service team to accept putting yet another agent, right, from their perspective into their -- onto their devices. So we've seen that, that approach has been really useful for us, given that we have a model where -- and so my leadership says this very eloquently. They hire really smart people and they give them problems to solve. They don't tell those people how to solve those problems. So when we deploy security controls and solutions, we do that in a way that allows for different teams to find the right fit for their particular fleet of servers. So I could have one team with a fleet of 30,000 or 40,000 servers and I can have another team with a fleet of 10,000 servers and 3 other teams with multiple tens of thousands in their fleets, and they're each going to be given various methods with which to sort of secure their environment and support around that. So for us, it's not a situation where we have this heterogeneous environment. We can just say, "All right, push this out to everywhere, right?" It's just not the way we work.

So we find that the Cloud Agent is a useful tool in the tool chest and we find that it can be really high-impact integrating into a CICD pipeline because every piece of software that you put onto any other system is a source of potential operational error and a source of security risk. So of course, we're going to want to keep that as small as possible. If we're able to effectively test on our lower environments and use modern development practices to push out to production exactly what we had just tested, that means that maybe we don't need all those agents in the production environment for, in this particular use case, detecting vulnerabilities. It's different for other pieces of like detection in terms of like malicious behavior or something, but for vulnerabilities, we find we can take a really efficient and targeted approach.

SENTHIL SELVARAJ: I think from our perspective, as I mentioned earlier, banking, taking a cautious approach, we are not that deep into the cloud right now. We have a lot of, I mean, variety of applications within our consolidated private cloud, if you will, or data centers. And we do use various products. I'm not exactly sure how -- which product we use for Cloud Agents and things like that, but we have the CASB solutions, the DLP and all that, mostly to secure our perimeter from externally facing applications and detecting their vulnerabilities, prioritizing and then letting us know so we can give that as a high priority. And we do measure that using a Board-level metric. So from that perspective, we have strong controls around whatever we have as an exposed surface, but not truly fully into the cloud. So I think probably that's future iterations. And when banks evolve a little bit more into the cloud and maybe explore infrastructure as a service, platform as a service products, we may try a little bit more, but I think most of our applications are secured within our private cloud area right now.

SUMEDH S. THAKAR: There's another question?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I have a quick one. So it seems like -- just wondering if you guys already have an existing vendor that's in play right now? And it seems like -- how are you guys thinking about adopting the vendor SIM solution just like Qualys announced today into your existing SIM operation?

And then lastly, just a quick initial reaction on the pricing model that was announced this morning.

CHAD SCHIEKEN: So I personally couldn't comment probably on the details of our SIM, what vendor we're using and that sort of thing. And I think the SIM is not a product that I personally run in my function, so I can't speak to the suitability or not. It's just not (inaudible) responsibility (inaudible).

As far as the pricing model, if I understood it, it's more bundled, right? Well, that was exactly what I asked for, right? The reality is that there's tools and capabilities in the platform. And given our environment where I might have different needs for different segments of the environment, it's really useful to have a partner that can say, "Okay. You can use the PDI module over here. You can use this other module over there." And what that does is that eliminates the need for me to go out to the market and look at other solutions, and it kind of does keep me a little bit in this walled garden, which I'll happily stay in as long as I continue to get the value that I'm getting.

WENDY M. PFEIFFER: I run Splunk. They're also a technology partner of Nutanix, so they run certified on our operating system. I am always looking for alternatives that have favorable pricing models and especially favorable scaling models. And so I did hear about pricing. I like the sound of that. Scaling, I want to see how the model plays out, but I'm interested.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Even if it's more expensive?

WENDY M. PFEIFFER: Well, I'm a pretty good negotiator. So it's maybe not as expensive as for others.

SENTHIL SELVARAJ: No. My response is similar to what Chad provided. So I cannot divulge on the nature of work that different vendors do for us, but we do have a variety of vendors and we do have our own end-to-end program from a SIM perspective and all that. But I think the demo that was presented this morning was very interesting in that it hit the nail on its head with the siloed nature of the process, plan, tools and everything and there is urgent need to integrate all these things. So I think there's a lot of value. It doesn't matter whether the companies go for their own end-to-end process and solution or they're up another vendor product. But I think that's the need of the hour right now.

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT: Okay. What I would like to say is that we have at 3 p.m., there is a presentation from Microsoft, which is speaking about building security into Azure. So if some of you would like to go, I mean, 3:00. It's not -- for those who want to continue the question, you can stay until midnight. So that's no problem. So -- so it's really okay. So okay. Thank you, guys. Thank you very much.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Philippe, would you like to say any closing remarks?

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT: Another closing remarks is that we have a lot of fantastic presentations to come. So you're all invited. And as I said, again, feel free to discuss with our customers and get their point of view. And again, thank you for coming here. Thank you very much.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Thank you.

PHILIPPE F. COURTOT: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5W8B-KWP1-F03R-N496-00000-00Qualys, Nordstrom, Alphabet, Amazon and Facebook highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQualys, Nordstrom, Alphabet, Amazon and Facebook highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the DayZacks Equity Research

Jun 04, 2019( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; For Immediate ReleaseChicago, IL - June 4, 2019 - Zacks Equity Research[1] Shares of Qualys, Inc.QLYS[2] as the Bull of the Day, Nordstrom, Inc.JWN[3] asthe Bear of the Day. In addition, Zacks Equity Research provides analysis on Alphabet Inc.

GOOGL[4], Amazon.com Inc. AMZN[5] and FacebookFB[6].Here is a synopsis of all five stocks:Bull of the Day[7]:Shares of Qualys, Inc. have been on a roller coaster ride over the last 12 months, including a big one-day drop Monday. Despite the recent turbulence, the cloud-based IT security and compliance solutions firm's stock is up big over the last several years and Qualys looks poised to grow both its top and bottom lines going forward.Overview Qualys' pitch to potential customers is simple. The firm boasts that it offers 'a single cloud platform for IT, security and compliance across' all of a company's 'global IT assets.' The firm's cloud-based platform and its integrated cloud apps provide business critical security intelligence continuously, which allows Qualys' clients the chance to automate 'auditing, compliance and protection for IT systems and web applications on premises, on endpoints and elastic clouds.'The Foster City, California-based company was one of the first security firms to operate a Software-as-a-Service model. This has become widely popular across the tech industry today, from Salesforce to more consumer-facing companies like Netflix and Uber. Qualys has strategic partnerships with some well-known consulting giants and managed service providers like Accenture and IBM and currently has over 12,200 customers around the world.Cybersecurity concerns are set to expand as the world becomes ever-more digitized and connected. In fact, roughly $600 billion, or nearly 1% of global GDP, is expected to be lost to cybercrime every year, based on a 2018 study by The Center for Strategic and International Studies and global computer security firm McAfee.Qualys is coming off top and bottom line beats in Q1 fiscal 2019. And as we mentioned at the top, shares of QLYS have outperformed over the last serval years. Qualys is up 154% in the last three years and 93% over the past 24 months, which blows away the Security Market's 31% average climb and the S...00's 12% jump.Outlook ...rnings TrendsLooking ahead, our current Zacks Consensus Estimate calls for the company's second-quarter revenue to pop roughly 15.2% from the prior-year quarter to reach $78.5 million. This would mark a slight slowdown from Q1's 16% top-line expansion. With that said, the company's full-year fiscal 2019 revenue is projected to jump 15.4% to hit $321.9 million. Peeking further ahead, Qualys is expected to see its full-year 2020 revenue surge 16% above our current-year estimate, in a sign of solid and stable sales growth.At the bottom end of the income statement, the security provider is expected to see its adjusted second-quarter earnings soar 20.5% from the year-ago period to touch $0.47 per share. Last quarter, QLYS crushed our earnings estimate by 16.7% to post adjusted earnings of $0.49, which marked a 36% climb. Meanwhile, the company's adjusted full-year EPS figure is projected to pop 10.3%. Plus, Qualys' 2020 earnings are projected to come in 14.6% higher than our current-year estimate.Qualys has topped our quarterly earnings estimate for several years now. This includes a 21.1% average beat over the trailing four periods. Investors will also notice that Qualys' earnings estimate revision picture has trended heavily upward recently, especially for fiscal 2019 and 2020. The firm's positive earnings estimate revision activity has helped lift its overall consensus estimates for both the current and following fiscal year, which means at least some analysts are more optimistic about Qualys' earnings growth.Bear of the Day[8]:Nordstrom, Inc. stock has tumbled 30% in 2019. This stands in stark contrast to the S...00's roughly 10% comeback, but is part of an increasingly worrisome trend among department store chains that struggle for relevance in the quickly changing retail landscape.Overview ...cent PerformanceNordstrom, Macy's, Kohl's, JC Penney and other more traditional department store-style retailers have found it harder to adapt to the e-commerce and delivery age. JWN and others have revamped their businesses to accommodate shoppers that have come to expect quick delivery and smooth, easy to use e-commerce platforms in the Amazon age.Wall Street and investors have, however, noticed that companies like Nike and Ralph Lauren have focused on direct-to-consumer expansion and big-box retailers such as Target have successfully attracted shoppers who might have been Nordstrom and Macy's customers in years gone by. Nordstrom has purchased Stitch Fix competitor Trunk Club and member-only shopping website HauteLook and focused on its off-priced Nordstrom Rack stores in order to better compete.Nordstrom's first quarter fiscal 2019 revenue slipped 3.3% from the prior-year quarter and missed our Zacks Consensus Estimate. More specifically, the top line was hurt by the company's loyalty program, digital marketing, and merchandise, which led to downturns across JWN's full-price and off-price businesses. Worse yet, the firm's adjusted Q1 earnings plummeted roughly 55% to fall well short of estimates.Shares of JWN have fallen roughly 14% since the company reported its Q1 2019 financial results on May 21. This recent downturn has pushed Nordstrom stock down 31% this year. Investors will notice that the company's recent performance is part of a much larger five-year downturn.Outlook ...rnings TrendsManagement lowered JWN's guidance for fiscal 2019 following Nordstrom's brutal Q1 showing. Looking ahead, the company's current-quarter revenue is projected to dip 3% to $3.94 billion, based on our current Zacks Consensus Estimate. Nordstrom's full-year revenue is expected to sink 1.75% to $15.58 billion. Peeking further down the road, the company's 2020 revenue is projected to jump 1.3% above our fiscal 2019 estimate. But this would still see revenue come in below 2018's total.At the bottom end of the income statement, the firm's adjusted Q2 2019 earnings are projected to fall nearly 16% to touch $0.80 per share. On top of that, the company's current full-year EPS figure is expected to slip 5.6%. Plus, Nordstrom has experienced a ton of downward earnings estimate revisions recently, especially for fiscal 2019 and 2020.Additional content:Google, Amazon ...cebook Fall as Antitrust Allegations Revisit Silicon ValleyAlphabet Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. stocks opened Monday down big, with Amazon down 3% and Google down over 6%. Both companies are facing speculation of an antitrust investigation. The U.S. Department of Justice is reportedly going after Google, while the Federal Trade Commission is trying to tackle Amazon and Facebook. Amazon closed the day down around 5% while Alphabet closed around -6.5%.Meanwhile, Facebook is just now nearing the end of the Cambridge Analytica scandal and will be paying $3-5 billion for its privacy violations based on reports. Facebook opened Monday down 3% amid the concerns around other tech giants and closed the day down around 7% as the FTC will reportedly be including Facebook in their antitrust investigation.DOJ InvestigationAlphabet's subsidiary Google is under pressure as the DOJ looks to open an investigation into "Google's business practices related to its search and other businesses," as first reported by the Wall Street Journal. With Alphabet being the tech power that it is, it's hard to know exactly what the DOJ is set to look into.Many of the worries seem to be focused on Google's collection of search data and control of the digital advertising market. Google's search engine currently claims about 75% of the worldwide search engine market share for desktops and that number is even higher for mobile and tablet devices. Google also made up 38% of the digital advertising market in 2018, 17% more than its closest competitor, Facebook.Google has faced many investigations in the past, paying out billions to the European Commission over the past few years. The FTC has also previously investigated Google, which ended with Google agreeing to pay a $22.5 million fine after denying any guilt.FTC InvestigationThe Federal Trade Commission has started the first steps of an investigation into Amazon. There is no clear sign of what the FTC will be specifically looking into, but Amazon's control in the online retail sector has always been an area of concern for politicians. This, coupled with its growing influence in multiple markets, make it a prime target.Amazon is also currently under investigation by the European Union who believe Amazon may be stifling competition due to its size. As seen with the previous Google investigation, the European Union is not afraid to fine these big tech companies in the name of consumer protection. The EU also tends to be significantly stricter than the US when it comes to regulation of these large companies.Facebook was added to the investigation after initial reports were focused on just Amazon and Google. The investigation into Facebook will focus on whether or not it stifles competition and has acted in an unlawful and monopolistic nature. This comes on the back of an FTC investigation regarding privacy issues and Facebook's user data collection.Public PressureThese investigations come after the companies and tech giants as a whole have come under bipartisan pressure from government officials. President Trump, backed by other Republicans, has accused Google of having biased search results and has had something of a personal feud with Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos.Meanwhile, Democrats have concentrated on whether or not these tech-giants cut off competition. Antitrust regulation has become a main focus of Democratic Sen. Elizabeth Warren's 2020 presidential campaign and her thoughts have been echoed by Sen. Amy Klobuchar and Sen. Bernie Sanders. With this much support behind the investigations, it could prove troublesome for the companies.This investigation is just in the very early days and although the government pressure is large, all these companies have large legal teams and resources at their disposal so it is nothing to be overly worried about at the moment, but should be watched as it continues to progress.Will you retire a millionaire?One out of every six people retires a multimillionaire. urn:contentItem:5XH2-79N1-JCMD-P50V-00000-00Quand l'Amérique a peur de ses géants2019-11-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisECONOMIEQuand l'Amérique a peur de ses géants

Revirement. Conservateurs et républicains s'attaquent à la toute-puissance des Big Tech.

fichier PDF de ce document

Au printemps, un grand panneau a fait son apparition dans le centre de San Francisco avec le slogan : " Démantelons les Big Tech ". De la provocation en pleine Silicon Valley. La candidate démocrate Elizabeth Warren, à l'origine de cet affichage, a déclaré la guerre à Google, Amazon, Facebook et Apple, ou Big Tech, comme on les surnomme, l'équivalent de nos Gafam.

" Aujourd'hui, les géants du numérique ont trop de pouvoir sur notre économie, notre société et notre démocratie ",affirme la sénatrice du Massachusetts. Elle appelle à leur scission et s'est engagée à refuser les contributions financières de leurs dirigeants. Evidemment, ça lui a attiré quelques inimitiés. Warren est une menace " existentielle ", a confié à ses employés Mark Zuckerberg, le patron de Facebook. Il a promis de " monter au créneau " et de " lutter "contre son programme de démantèlement. Sans attendre, Facebook a subrepticement escamoté quelques publici tés anti-Gafam de la candidate sur son site. Avant de les rétablir, devant le tollé suscité. Quel revirement ! Amazon et Cie étaient jusque-là vantés comme des modèles de progrès qui oeuvraient pour le bien de l'humanité. Mais l'industrie du numérique n'est plus en odeur de sainteté. On lui reproche de manipuler les élections, de propager des bobards, de maltraiter ses employés, de gruger le fisc, d'être le Big Brother du XXIe siècle... Seuls 50 % des Américains considèrent que ces groupes ont un impact positif sur le pays, contre 71 % il y a quatre ans, d'après le Pew Research Center. 50 % des Américains estiment que les Big Tech ont un impact positif sur leur pays, contre 71 %il y a quatre ans, selon le Pew Research Center. Jeu de massacre. Une fois n'est pas coutume, la droite et la gauche sont unies dans leurs critiques. Les républicains, Donald Trump en tête, accusent les sites de censurer les voix conservatrices. Les démocrates, eux, dénoncent l'exploitation des données personnelles et la désinformation qui, estiment-ils, ont contribué à la défaite de Hillary Clinton en 2016. Leur fureur est montée d'un cran lorsque Facebook a refusé, au nom de la sacro-sainte liberté d'expression, de censurer une pub totalement mensongère contre le candidat Joe Biden concoctée par l'équipe de Trump. Elizabeth Warren s'est amusée à lancer à son tour un spot annonçant - faussement - que Mark Zuckerberg soutenait la réélection de Donald Trump. Facebook l'a diffusé ! Signe du désamour croissant à l'égard des Big Tech, l'audition fascinante du même Zuckerberg à la Chambre des représentants le mois dernier. Pour l'occasion, il avait troqué son sempiternel tee-shirt pour un costume-cravate et s'est pointé avec une armada de lobbyistes et de conseillers en communication. Ce qui n'a pas empêché le jeu de massacre. Pendant six heures, les élus l'ont bombardé de questions souvent hostiles sur son projet de cryptomonnaie, la protection des données et le degré d'infox qu'il tolérait. " Pourrais-je, par exemple, diffuser des pubs sur Facebook contre des républicains disant qu'ils ont voté en faveur du Green New Deal [son projet de lutte contre le réchauffement climatique] ? "a demandé la démocrate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. " Je ne sais pas la réponse de tête ",a répondu le patron de Facebook avant de lâcher : " Je pense que oui, probablement. " " Le manque total de vérification des pubs politiques est-il, à votre avis, un problème potentiel ? "a poursuivi la jeune femme. " Je pense qu'il n'est pas bien de mentir et de placer des pubs mensongères,a-t-il rétorqué, visiblement mal à l'aise. Dans une démocratie, je crois que les gens devraient être capables de voir par eux-mêmes ce que disent les hommes politiques et juger de leur caractère. " Jusqu'à présent, les autorités de réglementation américaines avaient fait preuve de beaucoup d'indulgence à l'égard des Gafam. Mais, à mesure qu'ils s'emparent de pans entiers de l'économie, les plaintes se multiplient. Amazon, qui contrôle 50 % du commerce sur Internet, est accusé de privilégier les produits de sa marque sur sa plateforme au détriment de ceux vendus par des tiers. Google, responsable de 92 % des recherches en ligne, favoriserait, lui aussi, ses services et abuserait, avec Facebook, de sa position dominante sur le marché publicitaire. Quant à Apple, on lui reproche de faire la pluie et le beau temps sur la sélection des applications de sa boutique. Bien sûr, les intéressés rejettent ces accusations. Leurs services offrent de nombreux avantages aux utilisateurs et sont loin d'être monopolistiques. La preuve ? Par exemple, Amazon n'occupe qu'une faible portion du secteur de la distribution. 5 milliards de dollarsC'est l'amende que la Federal Trade Commission a approuvé en juillet. En septembre, c'est Google qui a été condamné à 170 millionsde dollars d'amende pour avoir recueilli, via YouTube, des informations privées sur des enfants destinées à les cibler avec des publicités. Plaintes. Le 9 septembre, un groupe de procureurs généraux s'est donc retrouvé devant la Cour suprême à Washington. Un cadre théâtral pour une déclaration fracassante. Les procureurs de cinquante Etats ont décidé d'ouvrir une enquête sur Google. " Il y a des indices montrant, selon nous, que ses pratiques commerciales ont pu réduire le choix du consommateur, étouffer l'innovation, violer la confidentialité ",a déclaré Ken Paxton, le procureur général du Texas. Ils ont également Facebook dans le collimateur. Et ils ne sont pas les seuls. Ces derniers mois, le ministère de la Justice, la Federal Trade Commission (FTC, l'équivalent de la Direction générale de la concurrence, de la consommation et de la répression des fraudes) et la Chambre des représentants ont lancé une avalanche d'enquêtes contre les Big Tech pour déterminer s'il fallait restreindre leur influence et moderniser les lois antimonopole écrites à l'époque des arrière-arrière-grands-parents de Zuckerberg. Vont-elles aboutir ? Sur quoi ? Il est trop tôt pour le dire. Les Etats-Unis n'ont pas une Margrethe Vestager, la commissaire européenne à la Concurrence. La FTC et le ministère de la Justice sont à couteaux tirés, le Congrès est paralysé par les divisions. Une chose est sûre : on s'achemine vers des batailles juridiques épiques, longues et coûteuses. L'un des obstacles majeurs auxquels se heurtent les régulateurs, c'est l'ombre de Robert Bork. Ce juge conservateur, décédé en 2012, a écrit en 1978 " Le paradoxe de l'antitrust ", dans lequel il reproche à la justice d'avoir fait preuve d'un interventionnisme excessif dans la lutte contre les monopoles, ce qui a nui à l'économie. Les juges, écrit ce chantre du laisser-faire, devraient se poser une seule question quand ils examinent un dossier antitrust : le consommateur est-il lésé, en clair, son porte-monnaie souffre-t-il d'une hausse des prix ? Cette interprétation très étroite de la loi, devenue la doctrine des tribunaux, a limité le nombre de procès (entre 1970 et 1999, il y en avait en moyenne 15 par an, mais ce chiffre est tombé à trois entre 2000 et 2014 et a favorisé d'énormes fusions). La philosophie de Bork a notamment protégé les Big Tech. Il est en effet difficile de prouver que le client est lésé lorsque Google et Facebook offrent des services gratuits et Amazon des produits bon marché. " Le seul fait qu'une entreprise grandit et innove plus que ses rivales ne conduit pas à la conclusion qu'elle a violé les lois antimonopole ",analyse Mark McCareins, professeur à l'université Northwestern. Lobbying. Une conception anachronique à l'ère d'Internet, rétorquent les critiques. Qui viennent de coins improbables. En juin, lors de la remise des diplômes à l'ultralibérale université de Chicago, le professeur Luigi Zingales a exhorté les étudiants à s'attaquer aux géants du numérique comme les colons s'étaient battus contre la Compagnie britannique des Indes orientales lors de la Tea Party à Boston. " Nos lois antitrust ne peuvent rien faire contre ce type de monopoles. Le monde a changé et inévitablement la position de l'Ecole de Chicago doit changer aussi ",a-t-il déclaré. Récemment, le magazine The American Conservative,avec des accents quasi marxistes, a dénoncé Bork et sa " révolution qui a sacrifié le petit producteur sur l'autel de l'efficacité et des produits bas de gamme "." Le modèle européen montre que les tribunaux doivent adopter une perspective plus large sur ce qui constitue un comportement pernicieux pour le consommateur ", observe William Kovacic, un ancien président de la FTC. Plus facile à dire qu'à faire. Outre l'hostilité des juges, les régulateurs sont confrontés à de formidables adversaires. Ces cinq dernières années, les Gafam ont déboursé des sommes record en lobbying - plus de 55 millions de dollars en 2018. Cette année, Amazon et Facebook arrivent en tête des entreprises américaines qui ont dépensé le plus pour la défense de leurs intérêts, selon le Center for Responsive Politics. Elles arrosent les hommes politiques, financent les think tanks, organisent des conférences et font tout pour museler leurs critiques. Google aurait ainsi eu la peau d'un chercheur du New America : dans un article, il s'était félicité des sanctions financières imposées au groupe par les Européens. En décembre 2018, le PDG de Google, Sundar Pichai, a été appelé à témoigner au Congrès sur ses pratiques lors d'une audition houleuse. Puis, dans la soirée, il s'est rendu à une grande réception de Noël organisée par Google dans un restaurant du Wharf, un quartier branché de Washington. Il y avait là des centaines de membres de l'administration et tout le gotha politique, dont Darrell Issa, un parlementaire républicain qui, quelques heures plus tôt, l'avait questionné lors de l'audition. 63 % des Américains qui se déclarent démocrates et 60 %de ceux qui se déclarent républicains approuvent un peu ou fortement le démantèlement des Big Tech par l'annulation de récentes fusions, telle l'acquisition d'Instagram par Facebook, selon un sondage YouGov/Data For Progress de septembre 2019. Démantèlement. Amazon a choisi, lui, d'installer son second siège à deux pas du Capitole. Jeff Bezos, son patron, a racheté le Washington Post, s'est offert une demeure à 23 millions de dollars voisine de celle des Obama et a embauché une centaine de lobbyistes, parmi lesquels un ancien responsable de la FTC, trois ex-élus au Congrès et un bailleur de fonds de Donald Trump. Mark Zuckerberg, lui, invite régulièrement des conservateurs influents à des dîners chez lui, dans ses propriétés de Californie. Sans oublier l'Association Internet, l'organisation corporative qui a décerné cette année son prix de la liberté sur Internet à... Ivanka Trump, la fille du président. William Kovacic reste confiant. Le climat politique a changé et il voit se profiler dans les douze prochains mois plusieurs procès. " Les procureurs des Etats et des agences de réglementation se sont engagés à agir avec ces enquêtes et ne peuvent plus reculer. " Reste à savoir quelles solutions seront préconisées. Les amendes ne sont pas efficaces, l'Europe l'a bien montré. C'est pour cela qu'Elizabeth Warren appelle au démantèlement. Amazon pourrait céder sa chaîne de supermarchés Whole Foods ; Facebook, WhatsApp et Instagram ; Google, YouTube ; Apple sa boutique d'applis... Dans l'Histoire, les tentatives de scission sont pourtant rares et n'ont pas toujours été couronnées de succès. Le premier grand exemple, c'est la Standard Oil en 1911. L'entreprise de John Rockefeller avait, par toutes sortes de magouilles, réussi à éliminer ses rivaux et à contrôler 90 % du raffinage. On l'a obligée à se scinder en 34 entités. En 1982, AT-T, qui détenait un monopole sur le téléphone, a été divisé à son tour en 7 groupes. Cette décision au terme de huit ans de procédure a donné un coup de fouet à la concurrence et à l'apparition, et a permis l'émergence, disent certains, de la téléphonie mobile. Les trois plus grandes firmes visées par la loi antitrustScission. La Silicon Valley s'intéresse plutôt au cas Microsoft. En 1998, le ministère de la Justice et une vingtaine d'Etats intentent une action contre le numéro un mondial du logiciel, accusé de favoriser son navigateur, Internet Explorer, aux dépens de celui de Netscape. Condamné à être coupé en deux, Microsoft fait appel et échappe à la scission. Il devra toutefois se soumettre à des restrictions, qui, de l'avis de nombreux experts, ont favorisé l'émergence des Gafam. " Il est fort douteux que Google soit devenu dominant dans un monde où Microsoft pouvait dicter le type de moteur de recherche utilisé dans chaque ordinateur de la planète ",estime Tim Wu, auteur de " La malédiction de la grande taille ". A défaut de démantèlement, les pouvoirs publics vont probablement contrôler de plus près les fusions et les rachats. Facebook a effectué " 67 acquisitions sans opposition, Amazon 91 et Google 214 ",a calculé Tim Wu. " Il est nécessaire également de mettre en place des règles et des lois spécifiques pour promouvoir la concurrence, car les lois antimonopole ne sont pas suffisantes ",ajoute Charlotte Slaiman, du groupe Public Knowledge. Parmi les mesures envisagées, une nouvelle entité de réglementation numérique, l'interdiction à une plateforme de vendre des produits sous sa marque, l'obligation pour les Big Tech de rendre leurs services interopérables, en clair qu'il soit possible d'accéder aux photos de ses copains sur Instagram sans quitter Snapchat. En 1890, le sénateur Sherman, auteur de la première loi antitrust, déclarait au Congrès : les monopoles sont " incompatibles avec notre forme de gouvernement. Si nous ne supportons pas un roi comme puissance politique, nous ne devrions pas supporter de voir un roi régner sur la production, les transports et le commerce. "L'Amérique n'a pas de roi mais elle a les Gafam
