urn:contentItem:5R0Y-46N1-JCMN-Y3GK-00000-00'Quantum Computing Changes Everything'2017-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexis'Quantum Computing Changes Everything'FP Editors

Nov 21, 2017( Foreign Policy: http://www.foreignpolicy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Alphabet executive chairman Eric Schmidt, left, speaks to Foreign Policy editor in chief Jonathan Tepperman at the Halifax International Security Forum on Nov. 18. (Halifax International Security Forum) On Nov. 18, Jonathan Tepperman, Foreign Policy's editor in chief, interviewed Eric Schmidt, the executive chairman of Alphabet (Google's parent company), at the Halifax International Security Forum. Video of the full interview is embedded below.

The following excerpt of the conversation has been edited for grammar and length. Jonathan Tepperman: British Prime Minister Theresa May recently lashed out at tech companies like Google, claiming that you weren't doing enough to counter violent extremism online. Just this week, the New York Times reported that YouTube, which Google owns, is finally taking down videos featuring Anwar al-Awlaki, the famous, now-deceased ISIS recruiter. What took you so long? And what are Google and Alphabet's other divisions doing to fight extremism and fake news? Eric Schmidt: All democratic countries are facing these challenges together, and the tech industry is also facing these challenges together. We are aware of them, we understand them, and we're working on them. With regard to YouTube, there have been cases where people have uploaded things that violate our terms of service or things that have been used incorrectly. We have very, very detailed terms of service, and after enough people mention [a problematic post], we typically look at it and decide. In this case, I think it was fairly clear. Perhaps it was overdue. Ten years ago, I thought that everyone would be able to deal with the internet because we all knew the internet was full of falsehoods as well as truths. Crazy people, crazy ideas, and so forth. But the new data show that [bad] actors that are trying to either spread misinformation or worse have figured out how to use that information for their own good, whether it's by amplifying a message or repeating something 100 times so people actually believe it even though it's obviously false. My own view is that these patterns can be detected, and they can be taken down or deprioritized. One of the problems in the industry is that we came from a naive position that these actors would not be so active. But now, faced with the data and what we've seen from Russia in 2016 and with other actors around the world, we have to act. [embedded content] JT: Say a little bit more about how companies like yours help fight fake news and violent extremism — and what you can do that governments can't. ES: Well, the first thing is that Alphabet created a company called Jigsaw, whose primary purpose is to analyze and pursue these issues. And the first project that Jigsaw did was to study violent extremism and the use or misuse of information. We also have internal groups that watch for this kind of amplification and manipulation of information and then try to deal with it. The most important thing that we can do is make sure that as the other side gets more automated, we also are more automated. Much of what Russia did [during the election] was largely manual. [But] you can imagine that the next round will be much more automated. JT: How do you think about the fact that you're inevitably becoming more aggressive in determining what people can and can't see? ES: We started with the American view that, in a crowded network, bad speech will be replaced by good speech. But that may no longer be true in certain situations, especially when you have a well-funded opponent who's trying to actively spread information. What everybody's grappling with is, where is the line? Everyone has an opinion. Nations have relatively broad definitions of where the line is, and [if you cross them], you're then subject to sanction, regulation, courts, and so forth. For example, the European Court of Justice has passed a rule that, under certain situations, when we're asked, we're required to take down personal information about people who are not public figures and not materially relevant to the conversation. But [the court] didn't define those two terms. If you're going to regulate that particular thing, you better be prepared to define it or figure out who's going to make that decision. We've found ourselves having to make that decision. I think we've done a really good job at it. But you could imagine an educated critic disagreeing. JT: You made headlines about two weeks ago by suggesting that the U.S. risks losing the race for artificial intelligence to China. What is the state of the competition today, and why is China such a threat? ES: The rise of China will be the big news for the rest of our lives. And I mean that in an economic, cultural, structural sense. China's artificial intelligence machine-learning policy, which I've actually read, says that they're behind us right now, but by 2020, they'll be caught up; by 2025, they'll be ahead of all of us; and by 2030, they will dominate. These are their words. There is no equivalent document that I can find in the United States, which invented most of this (along with Canada). And remember the Chinese have enormous resources in terms of smart people, educated technical folks, and a will to implement this. JT: But we have all those things, too. ES: They have more. They appear to have five times more [people] by math, and I'm very impressed by the quality of their work. JT: Is part of the equation that you didn't mention the role that the government plays there versus the role the government does or doesn't play here? ES: The Chinese model is very much government-driven, central planning-driven. There's lots of money and investment. They also don't have the kinds of privacy and data restriction rules that you would expect in a democracy. On the other hand, in our system, you have a thousand flowers running around, you have all sorts of new innovation from different things, you have a pro-immigration policy with respect to technical people (recently under threat). You have lots of reasons to think the United States, Canada, the Western world, can respond well. JT: You are a strong proponent of the value of AI. Others are less sanguine. We all know the risks that AI poses to jobs. But tell us how AI is going to transform international security. Do we all need to fear the coming of the killer robots? ES: Well, I think we've all seen those movies, and it's important to remind people that those are movies. Let's talk a little bit about where we are. Right now, the technology of artificial intelligence and machine learning is largely focused on very powerful pattern matching. The impact that it's going to have on society is probably first and most importantly in health care. Think about what doctors do. A lot of doctors are using intuition and their eyes. Literally examining what they see, reasoning, looking at patterns, and so forth. Those abilities that humans have are very well augmented. This is a case of doctor-plus. Not doctor-minus — doctor-plus. For the next five years, that's going be the big narrative. The other big narrative is the ability to use large data sets of information to find hidden cues of one kind or another, as well as finding patterns. Computers are very, very good at looking at very deep patterns that humans don't see. I'll give you an example. When you ask people what they'd like a robot to do, the thing that they'd like more than anything else is [for it to] clean up the dishes in the kitchen. That is literally the No. 1 request. That turns out to be an extraordinarily difficult problem — and why? Well, think about what it requires. You have to walk into the situation. You have to access where things are. You have to identify everything. You have to remember where it goes. You have to move in an appropriate way. And you have to do all this in real time. So it's much more likely that computers will be understood as savants, helping humans see deeper, plan deeper. My hope is that in 10-15 years you'll have physicists who will ask the computer a question, a deep physics question, and while they're sleeping, the computer will do an analysis of all of the papers, read them all, and come up with some other scenarios for this physicist to start to think about. JT: I still want to hear about the killer robots that you guys are working on. ES: In fact, we have a policy against building killer robots, so we're clear. JT: Tell us a bit more about how you see AI starting to affect major security issues in the not-too-distant future. ES: There's a movie where there's a drone swarm that's autonomously directed, gets released, and overwhelms the opponent. Now, what's the technology behind that? Well, today in universities in the United States, we already have autonomous drone swarms that we can demonstrate. You throw them all up, and they self-configure and figure out where they're going using principles derived from the animal world. You can imagine the implications there. My observation about the military is that it spends most of its time watching things. Well, humans get really bored watching the same thing, especially if it doesn't change. Computers don't. So a simple example of how this can be used is to improve the ability to detect changes. JT: Over the years, Google has taken on an increasing number of jobs traditionally done by governments. One recent example is Project Loon, under which Google's X deployed a number of high-tech balloons to Puerto Rico in order to supply internet connections that the federal government and the Puerto Rico government haven't been able to restore. As Google takes on more of these quasi-governmental functions, how should its relationship with government change? And how will Google balance its obligations to the public versus its obligations to its shareholders? ES: We celebrate that we're run under a set of principles. We stipulated this right from the beginning of going public, and we feel very strongly about it. Something like the Loon initiative has nothing to do with revenue. It has everything to do with making the world a better place. In Puerto Rico, for example, the government and telecom companies welcomed us. As long as we're on that side of these issues, we're going be just fine. JT: But what can the public do to ensure that Google does stay on the right side of these issues? ES: Well, you have a Congress, a president, laws, regulations, and so forth. We operate under the laws of every country we operate in, and we operate in pretty much every country. JT: What is the big tech-related security issue that none of us are thinking about right now and that we need to start thinking about? ES: One is the development of quantum computing and how that changes everything. Another is the rise of autonomy and its implications. Another is the fact that, from a military perspective, we're getting to a point where there's no place to hide assets. But the biggest problem is the fact that there's a generation of young people, a new set of brains and talent, that democracies need to get in their organizations at the national level, at the military level, at the NGO level, at the think tank level. The talent is there, but I have a feeling that they're not coming to you. Figure out a way to make your situations, which have very interesting problems, attractive, and you'll be in a much stronger position.

urn:contentItem:5YGJ-PDT1-JBJN-M0P8-00000-00Quarantined, but connected: The new (and difficult) experience of working from home2020-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQuarantined, but connected: The new (and difficult) experience of working from home


Many of us were hit and in some cases it was the only option, but not all of us were prepared. So, out of the blue and because of the coronavirus pandemic, several Chileans had to test for the first time the experience of telework (also called remote work or home office), a modality that in the US and Europe has years of use, but that in Chile is still found in diapers.


But there is interest in this modality. According to Google Trends, a tool that reflects the degree of google searches, Chilean users began to become aware of the new situation just this weekend, being the Metropolitan, Valparaiso, Magellan, O'Higgins and Maule regions who searched the related terms the most. The most recurrent queries in this case have to do with their implementation, the bill, and "slack", one of the most used tools in the business environment.
The same points to a 2018 study in which from 33 countries, Chile was the second in which people expected to do their work from home, with 74% of preferences.
Another scenario is mobile applications. Both Apple and Android iOS downloads include apps related to communication, meetings, and collaborative work, with platforms such as Zoom Cloud Meetings, Microsoft Teams, and Google's Meet hangouts as most required by Users.
In the face of the expansion of the virus, this mode of work became the most effective measure to protect the health of workers, although those who want to implement it are still on time.
Telework to the Chilean
"Telework is work," says Cristian Salazar, PhD in Information and Knowledge Society and academic at the Universidad Austral de Chile.
For the expert, "access to work is democratized, implies a cultural change in the employment relationship and how it is exercised. The low spread of these experiences in Chile has generated a number of myths, such as foreseing workers' rights, which involves working less, and that worker productivity will fall if they do not have direct supervision."
"It is not a profession, but a way of developing a task and requires a cultural reorganization for its efficient application. Culturally it has been difficult to change the ingrained concept of work, which is associated with a displacement action. Today we are facing a paradigm shift from 'going to work' vs 'doing it' anytime, anywhere," he adds.
"Therefore, both in schools and higher education centers we must educate the new generations that thanks to new technologies you can work from your own home ending the traditional concept: to work you need to be physically in the Company. Both teleworkers and organizations must be convinced that a teleworker can be so or more efficient and productive working at home," he says.
Legal obstacles
In this regard, Salazar comments that "one of the major obstacles that companies have reported is that in the current legal order there are no provisions governing the telework contract in a special way. In 2017 thanks to the Labor Reform, Art.22 was modified excluded from the limitation of working hours who work without direct supervision, being able to provide their services in their own home, outside the place or site of operation of the company, using computer or telecommunications means. So too, with this Reformation, those companies thathave a trade union membership equal to or greater than 30% of all their workers, their trade unions may agree with the employer on special working conditions, among which it may be telework."
Government to urgently provide telework project and SME grants are studied
"The non-existence of a law - as other Latin American countries do - that provides a regulatory framework that regulates the aspects of the contract of employment, rights, obligations and guarantees for both workers and organizations that adopt this modality, creates a fear in legally adopting the modality," he says.
Pros and cons
For the expert of the Universidad Austral, given the geographical characteristics of Chile, telework could help decongest big cities and allow people to work in the place of their choice to live and start a family: "Working there, live here and spend here," he says.
"Telework would decentralize large cities, and regions would stop losing talents that migrate to large cities where there are more job and development opportunities."
"Chile is a highly seismic country and having telework plans can ensure the economic sustainability of families and the operational continuity of companies that pay tax to the economy and society. Cultural change can transform us into a country that takes over new technologies by improving the quality of life of its inhabitants. Boosting telework will create new sources of jobs and new services that support the lives of teleworkers," he says.
Transition
According to Randstad Chile, following the announcement of the first case of coronavirus in the country, only 22% of companies adopted health safety policies against COVID-19, the most widely used being the dissemination of information on symptoms and good practices, followed by the execution of healthcare protocols, and restriction of business travel. Remote work was in the last places, being in fact one of the most effective solutions; around the world, ways are being sought to implement them quickly and strategically, with a particular focus on companies that are not prepared.
Ricardo Quezada Botto, Commercial Manager of Unnio Seguros Generales, notes that "thinking about the benefit of all, the first thing that happens in these cases is for companies to activate their contingency plans associated with disease threats or pandemic, focused on prevent contagion, support those who become infected and ensure continuity of business. The safest way to do this is through technology, using customer self-attention channels and working remotely in the face of the high risk of contagion."
Like any new process, this involves different challenges or insecurities in the face of transition. "The key is for the company to prepare technologically so that each of its employees is able to deliver the same value proposition to customers without affecting quality. A key is to transition slowly, testing through a schedule of days when you work from outside the office," he says.
Quezada ensures that when the work support becomes the technology, it should be prepared in terms of security, considering that those working remotely will be using home internet connections, who are more vulnerable to attacks Cyber. In Unnio they claim to use Cyberboxx, a technology platform that is used in these cases to monitor and respond to any cyberattack.
Generational Gap"This way of working is opposed to a workforce in the country accustomed to office hours. A study by Adecco revealed that only 28% of workers had facilities to work from home, while 72% said they did not have this benefit during the days of greatest conflict associated with the country's social awakening," says Mario Zúñiga, CEO of Zenta Group."Chile, the fifth country with the most hours of work and lower productivity according to the organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) figures, has very low labour flexibility. The concept of home office appears only in a few companies, although the path goes there: in most cases, you only need a computer, a good internet connection and a cell phone to get the job done."According to Guillermo Beuchat, founding partner of Transforme, there are also generational factors for this adoption. "The concerns of each generation are diverse. they live in the same business context, sharing responsibilities and tasks, but moved by different motivations, desires and attitudes to work and life challenges.""Baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, and who account for just over 25% of the workforce, show high levels of dedication and loyalty to the company, but they are uncomfortable with technology, and contradict 'the system'. For its part, Generation X, those born between 1965 and 1980 who add up to 35% of the workforce, have good skills for teamwork, focus on developing their expertise, always prioritizing family-work balance, and show openness to adopt Technologies. The so-called Millennials, born between the 80s and 2000s, have given much to talk about. This group is characterized as one detached to the norms and highly nonconformist, but with strong digital skills and autonomy that make them desirable in companies. Finally, Generation Z, born after 2000, has a much more optimistic attitude and are engaged in collective action. Their multitasking capabilities and quasi-technology addiction contribute a lot to the business context, but require other generations to give them proper supervision and guidance at work. These last two generations already account for 41% of the workforce."Tips
But telework isn't just about taking the computer and working from home. Claudio Torres, Regional Manager of D-Link, states that "the adoption of remote work requires companies to consider basic technical aspects, such as the quality of internet connection that employees have in their homes".
"It is important for organizations to accept that it cannot be done from home the same thing that is done in the office. There will be tasks that can be removed and others that will have to be redefined or adjusted according to the new conditions," he explains.
When working from home, the main recommendation is to enable a space dedicated to this activity, similar to what is advised in the case of students, in order to limit distractions. The D-Link expert also highlights the relevance of stable and quality Wi-Fi connectivity.
"It is relevant to understand that in our homes the connection is shared, this means that normal data traffic will be affected by simultaneous use among household members. For example, work-related video conferencing can be impacted by the use of streaming platforms, or by students' virtual classes,"Torres explains.
Finally, the expert warns about the importance of maintaining digital security standards in employees' homes. "Businesses should understand that it is not only enough for workers to have a laptop that they can bring to their homes, they must also ensure that people have the tools to establish secure connections to the resources of the company," he says.
In this sense, from ESET Latin America, a cybersecurity company, they share recommendations so that the organization can stay productive and safe at the same time. "It is important to note that companies and organizations must also prepare themselves and their employees to face the risks associated with cybersecurity with remote work," says Camilo Gutierrez, Head of the Research Laboratory of ESET Latin America.
- Physical security of the company's devices: As long as the employees do not take into account the security measures, they will be exposing the company's devices to an increased risk. Devices must be protected against loss and theft.
- Home technology environment: Ideally audit the vulnerabilities of the home environment before connecting the work devices, this is an excellent time to take steps to secure them with strong passwords and updating both the firmware like the software to the latest versions available.
- Access to the company's network and systems: Both cloud-based email and internal information, workers need access to the organization's network, but with all available security measures.
- Collaborative tools and authorization processes: Use collaborative tools to protect against unauthorized instructions or transactions. Cybercriminals are likely to take the opportunity to launch email attacks through a fake message, listed as urgent, requesting immediate transfer of funds, without the ability to validate the request in person.
- Training: There are numerous scams circulating that use the topic about COVID-19 in different ways. Computer security awareness training is often an annual requirement in offices, and it would be prudent to review to help prevent human error that cybercriminals seek.
- Crisis support and management: In the rush to provide remote access, not sacrifice cybersecurity or the ability to manage systems and devices.
Contingency plan
What are big tech companies doing to adapt to telecom/or
Ana Karina Ulloa, People Director of Movistar Chile, mentions that her company has more than two years of experience in the progressive adoption of remote work. "In 2019, 60% of employees adopted this modality, while today more than 80% of our employees work from home at least one day a week," he says.
"In the face of the current situation by Covid-19, we wanted to take an additional step in this new way of working, putting the health and integrity of our employees first. Progressively, we started our action plan, prioritizing risk groups (people over 60 years of age, pregnant, chronic or immunocompromised), who were the first to start remote work in this context. Subsequently, from Monday, many parents joined the care of their children - whose classes have been suspended - favoring not only theprotect their health, but also parental co-responsibility and work and personal reconciliation."
"As of Tuesday, we have privileged the remote work for all our employees, whose functions allow it, favoring the social isolation recommended by the health authorities, thus taking all the care and precautions to prevent the spread of coronavirus," he adds, ensuring that in relation to the tools, they use Office 365, Teams and Workplace.
Something similar happens in Samsung Chile, from where they claim that one of their own tools, Knox Mobile, is very useful with companies and workers in mind. The system separates the work and personal areas of the user into the same mobile device, with the aim of accessing the corporate network from outside their office, but keeping all sensitive information safe.
According to the company, it is basically the same security principle that applies on all Samsung smartphones, but carried to the corporate level. For example, today a Galaxy S20 or any device on the same line is already protected with Knox, meaning that it already has a mobile security platform at the processor and software level. However, with Knox Mobile for Business, companies can install and manage all Android corporate devices to their system at once, defining different criteria for access to information for each geolocation-based contributor, type of information and role.
"Although the company uses this service permanently for those who need it, in the current context it is being used more due to work flexibility policies for health prevention. In addition to implementing all possible preventive measures in their offices, high-risk groups (people over 60 years of age, with chronic diseases, pregnant women) and people living with this group, mothers or parents with children in suspended classes, among others, they can access to work remotely thanks to a VPN connection and Knox Mobile," says Bernardita Orellana, Communications Manager of Samsung Electronics Chile.
From Claro Chile they say that all the necessary technical measures are being taken to keep the network services operational and that users can remain connected at all times. Alfonso Emperanza, director of Claro, explained that from Thursday they will only open some branches to respond to the most urgent needs of customers. "Shift systems will be applied to reduce the number of executives and telework has been encouraged for a significant percentage of the company. Only those who are key to maintaining the connectivity of millions of Chileans will work in person. These measures aim to prevent and protect employees and their families, in order to help prevent the spread of the pandemic," he says.
Ariela Mendel, Marketing Manager of ASUS Chile, says that since this Tuesday all workers are at home 100% remotely, and even the company prepared before installing compatible systems for this purpose. "To continue working remotely, it is essential to make the most of the tools provided by the technology. In this way, we help to avoid possible contagion, taking care of our health and that of those around us," he says.
"In these circumstances of isolation, communication with other co-workers and meetings with clients are still very necessary. To hold meetings remotely, there are several tools that facilitate contact such as Skype, Hangouts, Zoom Meeting and MicrosoftTeams. Applications like MyAsus also boost performance and allow you to connect your computer with other electronic devices like your mobile phone, so you can control them without having them in front of you," he says.
From Google in terms of its collaborative tools G Suite, which allows you to develop the work thanks to products such as Gmail, Calendar, Drive, Classroom, Hangouts Meets, Hangouts Chat and G Suite for Education, in addition to implementing free access to Hangouts Meet's advanced video conferencing capabilities for all G Suite and G Suite for Education customers worldwide through July 1, 2020. Resources are also being added to support increased demand for live public streaming on YouTube, and reveal that they have seen greater interest in affected regions as people seek to virtually connect with their communities when they are not you can do it in person.
"As COVID-19 evolves in Latin America, seeking caution and in order to prioritize health and safety, we are offering our employees in the region the option to work from home," says Alejandra Bonati, Communications Manager Google Chile.
Online meeting apps
One of the most commonly used apps these days is Microsoft Teams, center for teamwork at Microsoft 365 where teams can chat, meet, make calls, and collaborate in a safe place. According to the company, since the end of January there has been a 500 percent increase in its use, as well as a 200% increase in the use of the platform from mobile devices. It will be free during the COVID-19 outbreak.
How is it used?
Individuals: Anyone can register for the freemium version of Teams from this link, or if they have a work or school email account, they can register from this link.
If you work in the education industry and want teachers, students, and administrators ready to use Teams, use Office 365 A1, a free version of Office 365 available to all schools. They can register from this link.
Webex: A solution that provides a set of software and video tools that deliver a secure, reliable, and on-demand collaboration experience on the web. Available for iOS and Android.
GoToMeeting: Online meeting software package, desktop sharing, and video conferencing that allows the user to meet with other computer users, customers, customers, or colleagues over the Internet in real time. Available for iOS and Android.
Skype: Free online calls, messages, international calls, etc. Maximum 10 people in video calls at the same time, and 25 per voice.
Houseparty: Only allows 8 users, but adds games to enjoy as a group.
WhatsApp: Allows video calls, but only from the phone and up to four people maximum.
Google Hangouts: Allows 10 people connected by video call, although in its business version it increases to 25 people.
Discord: It has no web version, which forces us to install the application. However, it is free and hosts up to 50 users simultaneously.
Zoom: It is free and allows group meetings of up to 100 users with a maximum duration of 40 minutes.
FaceTime: One of the popular apps for making video calls. You can invite up to 32 people to join a group call. When an invitation is received, people can choose tojoin using audio or video from iPhone, iPad and Mac. All FaceTime conversations are end-to-end encrypted, so they remain private and visible only to participants.

urn:contentItem:5YJ2-G5B1-JBCN-4227-00000-00quarantine;Tech is helping us work, connect amid pandemic2020-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 3quarantineTech is helping us work, connect amid pandemicAshkhen Kazaryan

In the past few years, the attitude toward tech has increasingly soured. Multiple data privacy and election-related scandals at various tech companies and a new political strategy of being tough on “Big Tech” have led to the phenomenon known as “techlash.”

In fact, in 2018, the Financial Times used that term to summarize “the year in a word.” And the hits just keep on coming: in 2019 and this year, we’ve continued to see even more calls to regulate technology and tech companies — with antitrust suits, congressional hearings and bad bills galore.

But as the severity of the COVID-19 pandemic sinks in, that desperately needs to change.

One of the major tools keeping us afloat right now is, of course, technology. Not every job can be performed remotely, and many brave people are going to work every day to keep the economy and the country from collapsing. However, a significant number of businesses, and even entire industries, have been able to move online. Zoom, Slack, Google Docs and other helpful remote tools have made this transition possible, though, admittedly, it hasn’t always been smooth.

Remote work isn’t the only area of our lives being sustained by technology during this period. Many churches are hosting their services online, and most schools and universities have switched to online classes for the rest of March — some even until the end of the semester. Political nominees are holding virtual town halls. Even AA meetings and therapy sessions are going digital.

It should bring us hope to see how society is adapting in all these spheres, desperate to persevere in the face of great odds. Tech, too, is being utilized for philanthropic purposes. Groups on social media platforms are forming to provide help to those in need and coordinate volunteer efforts.

As Fred Rogers said, “When I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me ‘Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.’” Technology has made it much easier to connect those helpers now.

Tech companies have also stepped up to the plate to try to help mitigate the crisis and its impact on the economy.

First and foremost, social media companies (Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, YouTube, Reddit, etc.) as well as hardware and software providers (like Microsoft and Apple) are actively combating misinformation about COVID-19.

For instance, Google removed thousands of videos that spread false reports about the coronavirus, and Apple’s App Store team issued new guidance for health apps developers. Facebook has also been aggressively removing false content and promoting official, trustworthy accounts. Many of the big and small companies are also working around the clock and adding critical updates to their interfaces in coordination with health authorities.

Furthermore,“Big Tech,” hated as it is, has been busy creating and protecting jobs amid the crisis, since the economy is relying much more heavily on e-commerce.

Amazon, for instance, is hiring 100,000 more people and raising employees’ pay, and Microsoft is continuing to pay its hourly workers (like shuttle drivers, cafeteria staff) their regular pay — even though there has been a reduced need for their services as many employees begin working from home.

Gig economy companies like Uber and Lyft have followed suit, offering two-week compensation to their drivers who have been quarantined or diagnosed with COVID-19. And Facebook announced a $100 million program that will give cash grants and ad credit to small businesses impacted by coronavirus. E-commerce powerhouses like Ebay, and again, Amazon, prohibited price gouging when some tried to use their platforms to sell necessities like hand sanitizer, cleaning supplies and toilet paper for outrageous prices.

Compared to all the previous pandemics in world history, there’s a new powerful tool in humanity’s hands — artificial intelligence.

As health experts work round the clock to stem the crisis, tech leaders have launched a database with copious amounts of scientific articles in an effort to help the scientific community around the globe in its research.

Google’s DeepMind division, for instance, is sharing all the findings and progress in studying COVID-19 that its algorithms are making. And the White House has called on artificial intelligence (AI) experts to help them connect the dots.

As the world does its part in fighting off the worst pandemic in our lifetime, technology, tech companies and the people behind them are the game changers.

Representatives of the broader tech industry were the first ones the White House ran to for help.

Will lawmakers and many policy experts revert back to their routine “breaking up big tech” rhetoric after the crisis is over?

Only time will tell.

Ashkhen Kazaryan is a Young Voices contributor, Internet Law and Policy Fellow at the IP Foundry and an expert at the Federalist Society’s Emerging Technology Working Group, part of the Regulatory Transparency Project.

urn:contentItem:5YJ2-G5B1-JBCN-41VK-00000-00quarantine;Tech is helping us work, connect amid pandemic2020-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 3quarantineTech is helping us work, connect amid pandemicAshkhen Kazaryan

In the past few years, the attitude toward tech has increasingly soured. Multiple data privacy and election-related scandals at various tech companies and a new political strategy of being tough on “Big Tech” have led to the phenomenon known as “techlash.”

In fact, in 2018, the Financial Times used that term to summarize “the year in a word.” And the hits just keep on coming: in 2019 and this year, we’ve continued to see even more calls to regulate technology and tech companies — with antitrust suits, congressional hearings and bad bills galore.

But as the severity of the COVID-19 pandemic sinks in, that desperately needs to change.

One of the major tools keeping us afloat right now is, of course, technology. Not every job can be performed remotely, and many brave people are going to work every day to keep the economy and the country from collapsing. However, a significant number of businesses, and even entire industries, have been able to move online. Zoom, Slack, Google Docs and other helpful remote tools have made this transition possible, though, admittedly, it hasn’t always been smooth.

Remote work isn’t the only area of our lives being sustained by technology during this period. Many churches are hosting their services online, and most schools and universities have switched to online classes for the rest of March — some even until the end of the semester. Political nominees are holding virtual town halls. Even AA meetings and therapy sessions are going digital.

It should bring us hope to see how society is adapting in all these spheres, desperate to persevere in the face of great odds. Tech, too, is being utilized for philanthropic purposes. Groups on social media platforms are forming to provide help to those in need and coordinate volunteer efforts.

As Fred Rogers said, “When I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me ‘Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.’” Technology has made it much easier to connect those helpers now.

Tech companies have also stepped up to the plate to try to help mitigate the crisis and its impact on the economy.

First and foremost, social media companies (Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, YouTube, Reddit, etc.) as well as hardware and software providers (like Microsoft and Apple) are actively combating misinformation about COVID-19.

For instance, Google removed thousands of videos that spread false reports about the coronavirus, and Apple’s App Store team issued new guidance for health apps developers. Facebook has also been aggressively removing false content and promoting official, trustworthy accounts. Many of the big and small companies are also working around the clock and adding critical updates to their interfaces in coordination with health authorities.

Furthermore,“Big Tech,” hated as it is, has been busy creating and protecting jobs amid the crisis, since the economy is relying much more heavily on e-commerce.

Amazon, for instance, is hiring 100,000 more people and raising employees’ pay, and Microsoft is continuing to pay its hourly workers (like shuttle drivers, cafeteria staff) their regular pay — even though there has been a reduced need for their services as many employees begin working from home.

Gig economy companies like Uber and Lyft have followed suit, offering two-week compensation to their drivers who have been quarantined or diagnosed with COVID-19. And Facebook announced a $100 million program that will give cash grants and ad credit to small businesses impacted by coronavirus. E-commerce powerhouses like Ebay, and again, Amazon, prohibited price gouging when some tried to use their platforms to sell necessities like hand sanitizer, cleaning supplies and toilet paper for outrageous prices.

Compared to all the previous pandemics in world history, there’s a new powerful tool in humanity’s hands — artificial intelligence.

As health experts work round the clock to stem the crisis, tech leaders have launched a database with copious amounts of scientific articles in an effort to help the scientific community around the globe in its research.

Google’s DeepMind division, for instance, is sharing all the findings and progress in studying COVID-19 that its algorithms are making. And the White House has called on artificial intelligence (AI) experts to help them connect the dots.

As the world does its part in fighting off the worst pandemic in our lifetime, technology, tech companies and the people behind them are the game changers.

Representatives of the broader tech industry were the first ones the White House ran to for help.

Will lawmakers and many policy experts revert back to their routine “breaking up big tech” rhetoric after the crisis is over?

Only time will tell.

Ashkhen Kazaryan is a Young Voices contributor, Internet Law and Policy Fellow at the IP Foundry and an expert at the Federalist Society’s Emerging Technology Working Group, part of the Regulatory Transparency Project.

urn:contentItem:5YJ2-YC91-JBCN-438C-00000-00quarantine;Tech is helping us work, connect amid pandemic2020-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 3quarantineTech is helping us work, connect amid pandemicAshkhen Kazaryan

In the past few years, the attitude toward tech has increasingly soured. Multiple data privacy and election-related scandals at various tech companies and a new political strategy of being tough on “Big Tech” have led to the phenomenon known as “techlash.”

In fact, in 2018, the Financial Times used that term to summarize “the year in a word.” And the hits just keep on coming: in 2019 and this year, we’ve continued to see even more calls to regulate technology and tech companies — with antitrust suits, congressional hearings and bad bills galore.

But as the severity of the COVID-19 pandemic sinks in, that desperately needs to change.

One of the major tools keeping us afloat right now is, of course, technology. Not every job can be performed remotely, and many brave people are going to work every day to keep the economy and the country from collapsing. However, a significant number of businesses, and even entire industries, have been able to move online. Zoom, Slack, Google Docs and other helpful remote tools have made this transition possible, though, admittedly, it hasn’t always been smooth.

Remote work isn’t the only area of our lives being sustained by technology during this period. Many churches are hosting their services online, and most schools and universities have switched to online classes for the rest of March — some even until the end of the semester. Political nominees are holding virtual town halls. Even AA meetings and therapy sessions are going digital.

It should bring us hope to see how society is adapting in all these spheres, desperate to persevere in the face of great odds. Tech, too, is being utilized for philanthropic purposes. Groups on social media platforms are forming to provide help to those in need and coordinate volunteer efforts.

As Fred Rogers said, “When I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me ‘Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.’” Technology has made it much easier to connect those helpers now.

Tech companies have also stepped up to the plate to try to help mitigate the crisis and its impact on the economy.

First and foremost, social media companies (Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, YouTube, Reddit, etc.) as well as hardware and software providers (like Microsoft and Apple) are actively combating misinformation about COVID-19.

For instance, Google removed thousands of videos that spread false reports about the coronavirus, and Apple’s App Store team issued new guidance for health apps developers. Facebook has also been aggressively removing false content and promoting official, trustworthy accounts. Many of the big and small companies are also working around the clock and adding critical updates to their interfaces in coordination with health authorities.

Furthermore,“Big Tech,” hated as it is, has been busy creating and protecting jobs amid the crisis, since the economy is relying much more heavily on e-commerce.

Amazon, for instance, is hiring 100,000 more people and raising employees’ pay, and Microsoft is continuing to pay its hourly workers (like shuttle drivers, cafeteria staff) their regular pay — even though there has been a reduced need for their services as many employees begin working from home.

Gig economy companies like Uber and Lyft have followed suit, offering two-week compensation to their drivers who have been quarantined or diagnosed with COVID-19. And Facebook announced a $100 million program that will give cash grants and ad credit to small businesses impacted by coronavirus. E-commerce powerhouses like Ebay, and again, Amazon, prohibited price gouging when some tried to use their platforms to sell necessities like hand sanitizer, cleaning supplies and toilet paper for outrageous prices.

Compared to all the previous pandemics in world history, there’s a new powerful tool in humanity’s hands — artificial intelligence.

As health experts work round the clock to stem the crisis, tech leaders have launched a database with copious amounts of scientific articles in an effort to help the scientific community around the globe in its research.

Google’s DeepMind division, for instance, is sharing all the findings and progress in studying COVID-19 that its algorithms are making. And the White House has called on artificial intelligence (AI) experts to help them connect the dots.

As the world does its part in fighting off the worst pandemic in our lifetime, technology, tech companies and the people behind them are the game changers.

Representatives of the broader tech industry were the first ones the White House ran to for help.

Will lawmakers and many policy experts revert back to their routine “breaking up big tech” rhetoric after the crisis is over?

Only time will tell.

Ashkhen Kazaryan is a Young Voices contributor, Internet Law and Policy Fellow at the IP Foundry and an expert at the Federalist Society’s Emerging Technology Working Group, part of the Regulatory Transparency Project.

urn:contentItem:5SM2-RTX1-JBJ7-N0RN-00000-00Quarter-end funding spike takes $A twist2018-06-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQuarter-end funding spike takes $A twistVesna Poljak

Funding costs are rising heading into the end of the June quarter, and a two-year high for the bank bill swap rate sends an ominous message for borrowers.

Funding costs are rising heading into the end of the June quarter, where a two-year high for the bank bill swap rate shows that although the Reserve Bank of Australia is on hold, the cost of finance can still increase materially.

Markets can expect a similar spike in the bank bill swap rate, or BBSW, in the lead-up to September's quarter-end, ANZ senior interest rate strategist Martin Whetton warned on Thursday. The rate will likely fall back in July, but the BBSW - which represents the short-term funding costs of the banks - appears to have moved firmly away from the levels achieved when liquidity was abundant.

More repo, or repurchasing, activity going on in the lead-up to June 30 means that cash is more expensive for market participants who have to reduce their exposures before the calendar year is ruled off. To do this they need physical cash or cash equivalents, largely for technical and regulatory reasons, but the impact of this has had a pronounced effect on BBSW at the March quarter-end too.

But this time, rates experts have noticed that Australian dollar financing has become sharply more expensive than its US equivalent. This is evident in the gap between three-month BBSW and LIBOR, the benchmark for US funding, over their respective overnight rates, which is at its widest in seven years.

This can also be observed currently in foreign exchange forwards, repo rates and in the cross-currency basis swap market, which is where investors can swap floating rates between different currencies.

"There's nothing to suggest that it's sinister just yet, we expect these things to be high as we get to quarter-end as the historical pattern shows," said Tamar Hamlyn, portfolio manager at fixed income boutique Ardea. "My feeling would be that it's a bit too early for a pronounced and sustained increase, these are wholesale financial markets. Most corporates don't refinance every day, but a lot of corporate borrowing will be tied to a bank bill swap rate plus a spread.

"If that rate remains high it is going to mean higher financing costs for anybody that's got variable rate financing in Australia, banks have to borrow money at BBSW as well."

The move is not being attributed to the updated composition of BBSW, which changed in May.

"There is a global dimension to this starting with the US," said Nomura rates strategist Andrew Ticehurst, who observes that multinationals outside the US are holding fewer US dollars. This is a consequence of President Donald Trump's move to incentivise US firms to repatriate money sitting idle offshore. The equivalent US bank bill rate moved higher and most reference rates moved in sympathy. It also meant, according to ANZ, that big tech companies would no longer be the marginal buyers of US Treasury bills.

That global dimension is missing in the run-up to June 30, Mr Ticehurst pointed out, where the move in Australia is not being replicated to the same extent in New Zealand, Britain or US. Some participants speculated that it was because Australian banks were inclined to raise more of their short-term financing in the domestic market instead of in the offshore market, but others believed this to be a strictly an anticipatory effect for now.

"Australia has a large need for $A funding reflective of local funding needs and Australia's current account deficit," wrote Richard Grace, Commonwealth Bank's chief currency strategist, on Thursday. At the same time, Australia's US-dollar funding needs are minimal.

The volume of repo outstanding is at a record high, according to ANZ, including the usage of repo by non-resident investors, which is at 52 per cent of total outstanding repo as of March.

July 31: Facebook's ad business outpaced Google's in Q2 - here's why
Though the tech giants have proven to be relatively resilient to the worst of Covid's impact on the advertising industry, the pandemic still stung: Facebook saw its slowest revenue growth since its 2012 IPO, but still saw an increase off 11%. Google, in contrast, reported its first revenue decline in company history.
The disparity was evident in the two companies' diverging stock performance Friday, with Google's stock slumping more than 3% at market close and Facebook's popping more than 8%.
Analysts said factors like the amount of revenue coming from direct-response versus brand advertising, exposure to areas like travel, and Google's sheer size gave Facebook's ad business a leg up over Google during the second quarter.
In notes to investors on Thursday and Friday, analysts explained why Facebook is enduring the pandemic better than Google. Here's what they had to say.
Source: CNBC

July 31: Facebook
Facebook equity rallied 7.4% after the company beat profit estimates by 41 cents a share, with quarterly earnings of $1.80 per share. Revenue also beat estimates. The social media giant also said it expects growth in ad sales despite a boycott by some key advertisers and cutbacks induced by the pandemic.
Source: CNBC

July 31: Facebook will add music videos after deals with labels
Facebook plans to launch music videos starting in the U.S. on Saturday after reaching deals with big and independent music companies in a move that could grab advertising dollars from Google-owned YouTube.
In a blog post, Facebook announced deals with Sony Music Group, Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group, Merlin, BMG, Kobalt and other independent music groups to launch music videos on its platform.
Users will be able to react to, comment on and share music videos on their news feed, on Groups and in Messenger. Artists with videos will include Blake Shelton, Diplo, Jonas Brothers and Nicki Minaj, the company said.
"Over time, the experience will become more personalized to your tastes based on artists you follow and videos you engage with," the post says.
Facebook said users will be first to see an official music video for a new song from artist Lele Pons.
Bloomberg reported in December that Facebook was pursuing the rights to music videos from major record labels in hopes to boost Facebook Watch. According to the report, Facebook's deals previously allowed it to use songs in the background of videos but it didn't previously have the rights to offer official music videos.
Source: CNBC

July 30: Facebook says the ad boycott is having an impact, but you wouldn't know that looking at its forecast
Facebook said in its second quarter 2020 earnings on Thursday it's been impacted by ad boycotts from major advertisers. But its third-quarter outlook suggests there won't be much of a ding to its ad revenue growth.
Facebook said its year-over-year ad revenue growth rate in the first three weeks of July were in-line with its second-quarter year-over-year ad revenue growth rate of 10%, and that its ad revenue growth rate for the third quarter will be "roughly similar to this July performance."
Major advertisers announced various degrees of pauses to their social media advertising budgets in June, after a campaign called "#StopHateForProfit" called on advertisers to boycott Facebook for the month of July.
Those organizations wanted to pressure Facebook into taking more stringent steps to stop the spread of hate speech and misinformation on its platform.
Facebook listed an "impact from certain advertisers pausing spend on our platforms related to the current boycott" as a factor contributing to its third-quarter outlook, and said macroeconomic uncertainty, a normalization in a recent surge in community engagement and potential regulation will also impact its third quarter ad revenue.
Wedbush analysts in a research note this week said they expected "minimal financial impact from brand boycotts." They wrote that given the duration of announced boycotts, it expects roughly $100 million of "near term brand revenue is at risk, representing less than 1% of [year-over-year] growth in Q3."
″#StopHateForProfit" organizers said in an emailed statement Thursday that the boycott encouraged Facebook to take a number of "concessions," but that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg "has not yet approached the type of meaningful action that we want to see."
"We called for a Facebook ad pause for the month of July as the mobilization for the Stop Hate for Profit movement.

July 30: Facebook says Apple's iOS 14 changes could hurt its ad targeting
Facebook Chief Financial Officer David Wehner said on Thursday that upcoming changes to Apple's iOS 14 operating system could hurt the social network's ability to target ads to users.
With the update to its mobile devices, Apple will ask users if they want to let app developers track their activity across other apps and websites. Apple has not said when iOS 14 will launch, but it's expected to roll out this year.
"We're still trying to understand what these changes will look like and how they will impact us and the rest of the industry, but at the very least, it's going to make it harder for app developers and others to grow using ads on Facebook and elsewhere," Wehner said.
Until now, advertisers could use a device ID number called the IDFA to better target ads and estimate their effectiveness. In iOS 14, each app that wants to use these identifiers will ask users to opt-in to tracking when the app is first launched.
The change is expected to start impacting Facebook's advertising in the third quarter but it will have a more pronounced effect in the fourth quarter, Wehner said.
The company forecast revenue growth for the third quarter of about 10%, beating analysts' expectations for growth of 7.9%.
"Our view is that Facebook and targeted ads are a lifeline for small businesses, especially in the time of Covid, and we are concerned that aggressive platform policies will cut at that lifeline at a time when it is so essential to small business growth and recovery," Wehner said.
Source: CNBC

July 30: Zuckerberg says there's 'no end in sight' for Facebook employees working from home
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg on Thursday said there is no timetable for when employees will return to the company's offices amid a continuing surge in Covid-19 cases in the U.S.
Zuckerberg made his comments on a call with analysts about Facebook's second-quarter results, specifically criticizing the Trump Administration for its handling of the coronavirus.
"With Covid growing quickly in the U.S., there's currently no end in sight for when our teams here will be able to return to our offices," Zuckerberg said. "It is incredibly disappointing because it seems like the U.S. could've avoided this current surge in cases if our government had handled this better."
This is not the first time Zuckerberg criticized President Trump for his handling of Covid-19. Zuckerberg made similar criticisms on July 16 on a publicly streamed call with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's leading infectious disease expert.
In May, Zuckerberg said Facebook planned to allow employees to start going back into its offices on July 6.
The company reported 11% revenue growth despite the coronavirus pandemic's effects on the economy and advertising spending, sending the company's shares up more than 6% after hours on Thursday.
Facebook's expenses in the second quarter were up 24% from a year earlier, excluding the company's settlement with the Federal Trade Commission a year ago. That was a smaller increase than in the first quarter, primarily because of a decline in costs related to travel and events as a result of employees working from home, Facebook CFO David Wehner said on a call with analysts on Thursday.

Shares of Facebook rallied above 6% after besting analyst estimates in the second quarter. The social media giant reported earnings of $1.80 per share, when Wall Street was looking for $1.39, on revenues o $18.69 billion, more than $1 billion above expectations.
"After all the sturm und drang about major advertisers boycotting the platform, Facebook shot the lights out," Cramer said. "Even better, July's going strong. July 29: Big Tech, including Apple and Facebook, report earnings after the bell, which could mean a crazy market day on Friday
Big tech could be about to make a big splash.
Four of the market's five biggest stocks report earnings within a single hour on Thursday afternoon and that could cause big volatility in after-hours trading and again on Friday.
Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook - worth nearly $5 trillion in combined market capitalization - are all are market favorites and are releasing earnings results just after 4 p.m. ET.
"Friday is going to be crazy," said Dan Niles, founder of AlphaOne Capital Partners. "If anybody misses their numbers, that's not going to be good."

Critics have launched a protest campaign.2019-05-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:54ZLexisNexisQuayside, Toronto's Google-linked smart city, draws opposition over privacy, costsSidewalk Labs is proposing a data-driven city of tomorrow. Critics have launched a protest campaign.Amanda Coletta

TORONTO - The Google sister company promised to transform a dilapidated stretch of the Toronto waterfront into the world's most technologically advanced neighborhood.

Quayside would be outfitted with robotic garbage collection, snow-melting sidewalks and self-driving taxibots. Sensors would capture data on park bench usage, air quality and more, aimed at making the neighborhood more livable.

It was handshakes and smiles all around when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and officials from Sidewalk Labs gathered here 18 months ago to announce the data-driven city of tomorrow. But internal discord and public criticism are threatening the project.

"I don't think they look so happy now," said Paula Fletcher, a Toronto City Council member. "This big idea isn't going exactly the way it was planned."

As in New York, where fierce opposition to Amazon led the online retail giant to cancel plans to build a second headquarters in Long Island City, a local movement here is growing to send Sidewalk Labs packing. The concerns: money, privacy and whether Toronto is handing too much power over civic life to a for-profit American technology giant.

The #BlockSidewalk campaign formed in February after the Toronto Star reported on leaked documents indicating that Sidewalk Labs was considering paying for transit and infrastructure on a larger portion of the waterfront. In return, it would seek a cut of the property taxes, development fees and the increased value of the land resulting from the development - an estimated $6 billion over 30 years.

Sidewalk Labs, a subsidiary of Google's parent company, Alphabet, said the reason it had not shared the proposal was that it was still being debated. But it was a tough look for a company that has come under fire over a lack of transparency around its business model and over the question of who would own and govern the data and intellectual property at the heart of its proposal.

"It's our job to remind everybody that no is an option and that consent is important," said Bianca Wylie, one of the leaders of #BlockSidewalk. "The way this process has been set up was not a question of whether we should do stuff like this, but how."

Separately, the Canadian Civil Liberties Association is suing the city, provincial and federal governments to shut down the project over privacy concerns. Michael Bryant, the head of the group, said Trudeau had been "seduced by the honey pot of Google's sparkling brand and promises of political and economic glory."

In the original "vision document" for Quayside, Sidewalk Labs described adaptive traffic lights that would detect when pedestrians and cyclists were at a light to ensure that they had priority to cross. Sensors would detect when benches needed to be repaired, when waste bins needed to be emptied and when bicycle lanes should be transformed into pedestrian walkways, or vice versa.

The vision document also mentioned "health sensors" but did not elaborate. A digital identification system would enable residents and workers to access services.

Sidewalk Labs committed $50 million to conducting year-long public consultations and creating a master plan to be submitted to Waterfront Toronto, a corporation that represents the three levels of government in developing the area. The plan would require the approval of the corporation and several government bodies to advance.

The plan is expected by the end of June - more than six months behind schedule.

The company has acknowledged missteps.

Micah Lasher, the head of policy and communications for Sidewalk Labs, said providing more details about the business model for Quayside and plans for data governance earlier would have helped allay many concerns. But he also said the business model remains uncertain.

Lasher said the company has struggled to figure out when to unveil ideas to the public.

"If you share them too early, they seem half-baked and you might move away from them later," he said. "If you share them too late, you are subject to criticism for not being transparent."

Long before the #BlockSidewalk movement and the civil liberties lawsuit, controversies had already provoked public skepticism.

Some of the disillusionment stemmed from the flurry of coverage about how tech firms, Google included, handle their customers' personal data.

Sidewalk Labs has downplayed links to its corporate sibling, saying it will not monetize the data it collects and proposing that it be governed by a data trust that would set the rules around its use.

Andrew Clement, a professor emeritus in the University of Toronto's faculty of information studies and member of a Waterfront Toronto advisory panel, said questions remain about the trust. Instead of answering them, he added, Sidewalk has been distracting people with new prototypes, such as raincoats for buildings.

Waterfront Toronto and Sidewalk Labs were both rocked by several high-profile resignations and dismissals last year. Ontario's former privacy commissioner resigned from a paid consulting role with Sidewalk because she said its plans for the data trust fell short of her standards.

Then, in December, Ontario's auditor general found that Waterfront Toronto gave Sidewalk Labs more information before a request for proposals than other companies that would be responding to the request.

According to the auditor general, Waterfront Toronto said it shared information with Sidewalk Labs as part of its regular "market sounding process" to gauge interest in the project, also shared it with some other groups and would have given it to any that asked. Waterfront Toronto said the information did not give potential bidders an unfair advantage.

The auditor general said that "fair practice and equal treatment would suggest that all potential bidders receive the same information at the same time" and called for greater government oversight.

Wylie, the #BlockSidewalk leader, said cities are relinquishing too much power to big tech companies as regulators are trying to rein them in.

But some worry that showing Alphabet the door would stain the tech-friendly image Trudeau has tried to cultivate for Canada.

"We believe that tearing up this process midstream poses reputational risks, trade risks and legal risks," Brian Kelcey, vice president of public affairs for the Toronto Region Board of Trade, told a parliamentary committee last month.

Kristina Verner, Waterfront Toronto's vice president of innovation, sustainability and prosperity, said that "the potential of this project is still very exciting." She said she does not see any harm in waiting to see Sidewalk's final plan.

"It is definitely not a done deal," she said.
